Aaron Sloman:
- Aaron Sloman is a philosopher and researcher on artificial intelligence and cognitive science
- He held the Chair in Artificial Intelligence and Cognitive Science at the School of Computer Science at the University of Birmingham and previously at the University of Sussex
- Sloman has published widely on philosophy of mathematics, epistemology, cognitive science, and artificial intelligence and collaborated with biologist Jackie Chappell on the evolution of intelligence
- He was born in Southern Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) to Lithuanian Jewish parents, and went to school in Cape Town before earning a degree in Mathematics and Physics at the University of Cape Town and a DPhil in philosophy at the University of Oxford
- Sloman's philosophical ideas were influenced by Immanuel Kant, Gottlob Frege, Karl Popper and others, and his work in AI by Marvin Minsky and John McCarthy
- He is a Fellow of several AI and philosophy associations and received the K. Jon Barwise Prize for contributions to philosophy and computing from the American Philosophical Association in 2020
- Sloman has published numerous papers and presentations, including The Computer Revolution in Philosophy, which emphasized the importance of architectures in AI and philosophy
Abhay Bhushan:
- Abhay Bhushan Pandey is an Indian computer scientist.
- He made significant contributions to the development of the Internet TCP/IP architecture.
- He is the author of the File Transfer Protocol and early versions of email protocols.
- He graduated from the first batch of Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur in 1965 with a B.Tech in electrical engineering.
- He received a Masters in electrical engineering and a degree in Management from the MIT Sloan School of Management.
- He worked on developing FTP and email protocols for ARPANet and subsequent Internet.
- He was a Director at the Institute of Engineering and Rural Technology in Allahabad and a senior manager in Engineering and Development of Xerox.
- He was a co-founder of YieldUP International and Portola Communications.
- He is currently chairman of Asquare Inc., Secretary of Indians for Collective Action and former President of the IIT-Kanpur Foundation.
Adam Dunkels:
- Adam Dunkels is a Swedish computer scientist and entrepreneur
- He is the founder of Thingsquare, an Internet of things product development business
- Dunkels focuses on computer networking technology and distributed communication for small embedded systems and devices
- He attended the Swedish Institute of Computer Science, earning a B.S., M.S., and Ph.D.
- Dunkels is known for his work on the uIP and lwIP TCP/IP Internet protocol suite and for inventing protothreads and the operating system Contiki
- He co-authored the book Interconnecting Smart Objects with IP: the Next Internet and founded the Internet Protocol for Smart Objects Alliance
- Dunkels has received various awards for his work, including the TR35 list of top innovators under 35 and the ACM SIGOPS EuroSys Roger Needham PhD award
- His small implementations have been used in commercial products by companies such as ABB, Cisco Systems, and Volvo Technology
- Some of his notable implementations include Protothreads, uIP, Contiki, and lwIP.
Adele Goldberg (computer scientist):
- Adele Goldberg is an American computer scientist, born July 22, 1945 in Cleveland, Ohio.
- She co-developed the programming language Smalltalk-80 and various concepts related to object-oriented programming at Xerox Palo Alto Research Center (PARC) in the 1970s.
- Goldberg earned a bachelor's degree in mathematics at the University of Michigan in 1967, and a master's (1969) and PhD (1973) in information science at the University of Chicago, where she completed her dissertation while working at Stanford University.
- Goldberg served as manager of the System Concepts Laboratory at PARC, where she developed Smalltalk-80 with Alan Kay and other researchers, introducing a programming environment of overlapping windows on graphic display screens.
- Many of Goldberg's concepts became the basis for graphical user interfaces, and Steve Jobs demanded a demonstration of the Smalltalk System before incorporating ideas into Apple's Macintosh environment.
- Goldberg left PARC in 1988 to cofound ParcPlace Systems, a company that created development tools for Smalltalk-based applications, and cofounded Neometron, Inc. in 1999, an Internet support provider.
- Goldberg has received numerous awards and honors, including the ACM Software Systems Award in 1987 and admission to the Women in Technology International Hall of Fame in 2010.
- The Computer History Museum has a collection of Goldberg's working documents, reports, publications, and videos related to her work on Smalltalk.
- Goldberg's publications include books on Smalltalk-80: The Language and Its Implementation (1983), The Interactive Programming Environment (1983), and The Language (1989).
Adi Shamir:
- Adi Shamir is an Israeli cryptographer.
- He co-invented the RSA algorithm with Ron Rivest and Len Adleman.
- He is also a co-inventor of the Feige-Fiat-Shamir identification scheme with Uriel Feige and Amos Fiat.
- He has made contributions to the field of cryptography and computer science, including the discovery of differential cryptanalysis.
- He received a BSc in mathematics from Tel Aviv University and an MSc and PhD in Computer Science from the Weizmann Institute.
- He has received numerous awards and honors, including the ACM Turing Award, the Paris Kanellakis Theory and Practice Award, and the Japan Prize in the field of Electronics, Information and Communication.
- He was elected a Foreign Member of the Royal Society (ForMemRS) and a Member of the American Philosophical Society.
Adriaan van Wijngaarden:
- Adriaan "Aad" van Wijngaarden was a Dutch mathematician and computer scientist who promoted the mathematical aspects of computing.
- He received a degree in mechanical engineering from Delft University of Technology in 1939.
- Van Wijngaarden became head of the Computing Department of the Mathematisch Centrum (MC) in Amsterdam in 1947.
- He worked on the construction of the first Dutch computer, the ARRA, in 1952.
- Van Wijngaarden was one of the designers of the original ALGOL language and later ALGOL 68.
- He developed a two-level type of formal grammar known as a Van Wijngaarden grammar.
- In 1962, he became a member of the International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP) IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi.
- The Van Wijngaarden Awards are named in his honor and are awarded every 5 years from the 60th anniversary of the Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica in 2006.
- Four individuals have been awarded the Van Wijngaarden Awards so far: Nancy Lynch, Persi Diaconis, Éva Tardos, John C. Butcher, Xavier Leroy, Sara van de Geer, Marta Kwiatkowska, and Susan Murphy.
- Van Wijngaarden died on February 7, 1987.
Alan Dix:
- Alan John Dix is a British author, researcher, and university professor specializing in human-computer interaction (HCI).
- He is one of the four co-authors of the university-level textbook Human-Computer Interaction.
- Dix is the Director of the Computational Foundry at Swansea University since May 2018.
- He was previously a professor at Lancaster University.
- Dix has authored several books, including Human-Computer Interaction (1st, 2nd, and 3rd editions) and Formal Methods for Interactive Systems.
- He has also contributed to the book People and Computers III with a chapter titled "Myth of the Infinitely Fast Machine."
- Additionally, Dix has a personal website and has been a part of the International Mathematical Olympiad.
Alan Edelman:
- Alan Stuart Edelman is a mathematician and computer scientist.
- He is a professor of applied mathematics at MIT and a Principal Investigator at the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL).
- In 2004, he founded Interactive Supercomputing which was later acquired by Microsoft.
- Edelman is a fellow of various prestigious societies and academies in the field such as American Mathematical Society, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, and Association for Computing Machinery.
- His research interests include high-performance computing, numerical computation, linear algebra, and random matrix theory.
- Edelman is known for his contributions to the Julia programming language, parallel computing, and the Future Fast Fourier transform.
- He has received numerous awards for his research including the Gordon Bell Prize, Chauvenet Prize, and Lester R. Ford Award, among others.
- He became a Fellow of SIAM in 2011, the American Mathematical Society in 2015, an IEEE Fellow Class in 2018, and an ACM Fellow of Class 2020.
- Edelman’s contributions to random matrix theory and numerical linear algebra are notable.
Alan Kay:
- Alan Curtis Kay is an American computer scientist.
- He is known for his pioneering work on object-oriented programming and windowing graphical user interface design.
- He led the design and development of the first modern windowed computer desktop interface at Xerox PARC.
- He also led the development of the influential object-oriented programming language Smalltalk.
- He has been elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the National Academy of Engineering, and the Royal Society of Arts.
- He received the Turing award in 2003.
- Kay is a former professional jazz guitarist, composer, and theatrical designer.
- He is also an amateur classical pipe organist.
- Kay attended the University of Utah College of Engineering and worked with David C. Evans and Ivan Sutherland.
- He joined the Xerox PARC research staff in Palo Alto, California in 1970.
- Kay conceived the Dynabook concept, a key progenitor of laptop and tablet computers and the e-book.
- He has worked as Chief Scientist at Atari and an Apple Fellow.
- Kay founded the Viewpoints Research Institute in 2001, a nonprofit organization dedicated to children, learning, and advanced software development.
- He collaborated with others to start the open source Squeak version of Smalltalk.
- Kay has lectured extensively on the idea that the computer revolution is very new, and all of the good ideas have not been universally implemented.
- He has received many awards and honors, including the ACM Turing Award and honorary doctorates from several universities.
Alan Mycroft:
- Alan Mycroft is a professor at the Computer Laboratory, University of Cambridge.
- He is a Fellow of Robinson College, Cambridge, and the director of studies for computer science.
- Mycroft completed his PhD in Edinburgh with a thesis on Abstract interpretation and optimising transformations for applicative programs.
- His research interests are in programming languages, software engineering, and algorithms.
- Mycroft co-created the Norcroft C compiler with Arthur Norman.
- He is also a named trustee of the Raspberry Pi Foundation, a charitable organization that promotes basic computer science education.
- Mycroft has four children.
Alan Perlis:
- Alan Jay Perlis was an American computer scientist and professor at Purdue University, Carnegie Mellon University, and Yale University.
- He was born in Pittsburgh in 1922 and received his bachelor's degree in chemistry from Carnegie Institute of Technology in 1943.
- He earned a master's and Ph.D. in mathematics at MIT and wrote his dissertation on "Integral Equations, Their Solution by Iteration and Analytic Continuation."
- Perlis participated in Project Whirlwind in 1952 and was eventually appointed the first head of the computer science department at Carnegie Mellon University.
- In 1962, he was elected president of the Association for Computing Machinery and won the first Turing Award in 1966 for his work on the programming language ALGOL and Internal Translator.
- Perlis moved to Yale University in 1971 to take the chair of computer science and was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 1977.
- He wrote an article, "Epigrams on Programming," in 1982, distilling his programming wisdom into one-sentence quotes.
- He passed away in 1990 and left behind a notable list of publications, including "An Introductory Course in Computer Programming" and "In Praise of APL: A Language for Lyrical Programming."
Alberto Ciaramella:
- Alberto Ciaramella is an Italian computer engineer and scientist.
- He obtained a Laurea in Electronic Engineering and the Post-Laurea in 1969 at La Sapienza University in Rome.
- Ciaramella is notable for extensive pioneering contributions in the field of speech technologies and applied natural language processing.
- He has published 40 papers and holds four patents.
- Ciaramella worked at CSELT as a research engineer and co-authored some of the first international patents for speech recognition and speaker recognition.
- He co-founded IntelliSemantic and continues research in applied language technologies.
- In 2010 he co-authored a paper about the application of emerging "semantic" technologies to patent analysis.
- Ciaramella participated in European projects focused on speech recognition and dialogue systems on many European languages, such as Italian.
Alexander Dewdney:
- Alexander Keewatin Dewdney is a Canadian mathematician, computer scientist, author, filmmaker, and conspiracy theorist. 
- He was born in London, Ontario and is the son of Canadian artist and author Selwyn Dewdney.
- He has made a number of experimental films including Malanga, Four Girls, Scissors, and the Maltese Cross Movement. He has also written two novels: The Planiverse and Hungry Hollow: The Story of a Natural Place.
- Dewdney has written a number of books on mathematics, computing, and bad science and founded and edited a magazine on recreational programming called Algorithm. 
- He was a co-inventor of programming game Core War and has worked on biology as a field ecologist and mathematical biologist. 
- Dewdney is a member of the 9/11 truth movement and has theorized that the planes used in the September 11 attacks were flown by remote control.
- He has published over 10 books on scientific possibilities and puzzles.
Alexander Stepanov:
- Alexander Alexandrovich Stepanov is a Russian-American computer programmer.
- He is an advocate of generic programming and is best known as the primary designer and implementer of the C++ Standard Template Library.
- He started to develop the C++ Standard Template Library in 1992 while employed at HP Labs.
- He convinced his colleagues at General Electric Research and Development to pursue generic programming and developed an Ada library for list processing in 1987.
- He recognized that C++ was more likely to become widely used and provide good support for generic programming, leading to the development of the C++ Standard Template Library.
- He is also the author of two books, Elements of Programming (with Paul McJones) and From Mathematics to Generic Programming (with Daniel E. Rose).
- He retired from A9.com in January 2016.
Alfred Aho:
- Alfred Vaino Aho is a Canadian computer scientist.
- He is best known for his work on programming languages, compilers, and related algorithms, and his textbooks on the art and science of computer programming.
- Aho was elected into the National Academy of Engineering in 1999 for his contributions to the fields of algorithms and programming tools.
- He and his long-time collaborator Jeffrey Ullman are the recipients of the 2020 Turing Award, generally recognized as the highest distinction in computer science.
- He received a B.A.Sc., M.A., and Ph.D. in Engineering Physics, Electrical Engineering/Computer Science from the University of Toronto and Princeton University.
- Aho conducted research at Bell Labs from 1967 to 1991, and again from 1997 to 2002 as Vice President of the Computing Sciences Research Center.
- Since 1995, he has held the Lawrence Gussman Professorship in Computer Science at Columbia University, where he has also served as the department chair.
- Aho is widely known for his co-authorship of the AWK programming language with Peter J. Weinberger and Brian Kernighan.
- He has authored or co-authored many textbooks, including the famous "dragon books" on compiler design.
- Aho has received many prestigious honors, including the IEEE's John von Neumann Medal and membership in the National Academy of Engineering.
Alston Householder:
- Alston Scott Householder is an American mathematician.
- He specialized in mathematical biology and numerical analysis.
- He invented the Householder transformation and Householder's method.
- Householder received a PhD from the University of Chicago in 1937 for his thesis on the calculus of variations.
- He worked on mathematical biology with Nicolas Rashevsky at the University of Chicago, then shifted to numerical analysis while at Oak Ridge National Laboratory.
- Householder contributed to the organisation of research, serving as president of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics.
- He was married twice and had two children.
- Some of his selected works include "Discussion of a set of points in terms of their mutual distances", a pioneer paper in multidimensional scaling, and "The theory of matrices in numerical analysis".
- Householder died in Malibu, California in 1993.
Amir Pnueli:
- Amir Pnueli was an Israeli computer scientist
- He received a Bachelor's degree in mathematics from the Technion and a Ph.D. in applied mathematics from the Weizmann Institute of Science
- He is known for his work in temporal logic and model checking
- He founded and was the first chair of the computer science department at Tel Aviv University
- He received the Turing Award in 1996 for his contributions to program and systems verification
- He also founded two startup technology companies during his career
- He died on November 2, 2009, of a brain hemorrhage
- He received several awards and honors, including the Israel Prize for computer science in 2000
- The Weizmann Institute of Science presents a memorial lecture series in his honor.
Anders P. Ravn:
- Anders Peter Ravn was a Danish computer scientist born in Venezuela in 1947.
- He received a Master of Science in Computer Science and Mathematics from the University of Copenhagen in 1973 and a Doctor of Technology in Computer Science from the Technical University of Denmark in 1995.
- He was a teaching assistant at the University of Copenhagen, worked as a systems programmer at A/S Regnecentralen and held various academic positions at different institutions, including guest researcher at Oxford University and visiting professor at the University of Kiel in Germany.
- Ravn specialized in research into formal methods, especially for embedded and hybrid systems. He worked on the development of duration calculus for real-time systems with Zhou Chaochen and Tony Hoare.
- He was a member of the Dansk Selskab for Datalogi, the Association for Computing Machinery and the IEEE Computer Society.
- Ravn received Ulrik and Marie Brinch's honorary award in 1996 and was honoured as a Knight of the Order of the Dannebrog in 2015.
- Ravn produced many research papers and edited several books.
- He died in Copenhagen in 2019.
Andrew Barto:
- Andrew G. Barto is an American computer scientist and Professor Emeritus at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
- He received his B.S. in mathematics from the University of Michigan in 1970 and later earned a Ph.D. in computer science for his work on cellular automata.
- Barto joined the faculty at UMass in 1977, was department chair from 2007 to 2011, and co-directed the Autonomous Learning Laboratory.
- He has published over 100 papers, co-authored the influential book Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction, and edited the Handbook of Learning and Approximate Dynamic Programming.
- Barto has been recognized with several awards, including the UMass Neurosciences Lifetime Achievement Award, the IEEE Neural Network Society Pioneer Award, and the IJCAI Award for Research Excellence.
- He is a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, a Senior Member of the IEEE, and a member of the American Association for Artificial Intelligence and the Society for Neuroscience.
Andrew Chi-Chih Yao:
- Andrew Chi-Chih Yao is a Chinese computer scientist and computational theorist.
- He is currently a professor and the dean of the Institute for Interdisciplinary Information Sciences at Tsinghua University.
- Yao used the minimax theorem to prove what is known as Yao's Principle.
- He was born in Shanghai and completed his education at National Taiwan University, Harvard University, and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
- He has worked as a professor at various universities including Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Stanford University, University of California, Berkeley, and Princeton University.
- In 2015, he renounced his U.S. citizenship and became an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.
- Yao has received various awards including the Knuth Prize, the Turing Award, and the Kyoto Prize in Advanced Technology.
- He is a member of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences, a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and a fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery.
- Yao's wife, Frances Yao, is also a theoretical computer scientist.
- Some of his notable works include Yao's test, Yao's Millionaires' Problem, and Garbled circuit.
Andrew Donald Booth:
-Andrew Donald Booth was a British electrical engineer, physicist, and computer scientist.
-He developed the magnetic drum memory for computers and Booth's multiplication algorithm.
-Booth worked at Birkbeck College, University of London where he built some of the first electronic computers in the UK.
-He founded the department of numerical automation at Birkbeck and did pioneering work in machine translation.
-Booth served as the President of Lakehead University from 1972-1978.
-He married mathematician and computer engineer Kathleen Britten and together they produced three computing machines.
-Booth's works and bibliography can be found in the Andrew Booth Collection at the University of Manchester Library.
Andrew Herbert:
- Andrew James Herbert is a British computer scientist and former Chairman of Microsoft Research for Europe, Middle East, and Africa.
- He received a BSc in computational science from Leeds University in 1975 and a PhD in computer science from Cambridge University in 1978.
- He worked at the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory from 1978 to 1985 and founded Architecture Projects Ltd in 1985, which developed ANSA, an advanced network systems architecture.
- He also founded Digitivity in 1996 to develop a product for secure deployment of Java clients and joined Citrix Systems in 1998 after their acquisition of APM and Digitivity.
- Herbert joined Microsoft Research in 2001 and became managing director in 2003 and chairman in 2010 before retiring in 2011.
- He is a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering and the British Computer Society, and a former Liveryman of the City of London Worshipful Company of Information Technologists.
- Herbert's research interests include computer networking, operating systems, distributed computing, programming languages, and large-scale data-driven systems.
- His significant research achievements include the Cambridge CAP Computer operating system, and contributions to the Cambridge Model Distributed System and Advanced Networked Systems Architecture.
- He has published several books and articles and is currently chairman of trustees for the National Museum of Computing at Bletchley Park.
- Herbert also manages a project to construct a working replica of the Cambridge EDSAC computer at the museum, which is expected to be operational in 2021.
Andrew Koenig (programmer):
- Andrew Richard Koenig is a former AT&T and Bell Labs researcher and programmer who has authored books such as C Traps and Pitfalls, Accelerated C++, and Ruminations on C++. 
- He has also served as the Project Editor of the ISO/ANSI standards committee for C++ and has authored over 150 papers on the language. 
- Koenig is associated with argument-dependent name lookup, also known as "Koenig lookup," and has been involved in several patents related to computer programming. 
- He was born in New York City and graduated from Columbia University, where he was a prominent member of the Columbia University Center for Computing Activities. 
- Koenig retired from Bell Labs in Murray Hill, New Jersey.
Andrew McCallum:
- Andrew McCallum is a professor in the computer science department at University of Massachusetts Amherst.

- His specialties are in machine learning, natural language processing, information extraction, information integration, and social network analysis.

- McCallum graduated summa cum laude from Dartmouth College in 1989.

- He completed his Ph.D. at University of Rochester in 1995 and was a postdoctoral fellow at Carnegie Mellon University.

- From 1998 to 2000, he was a Research Scientist and Research Coordinator at Justsystem Pittsburgh Research Center.

- From 2000 to 2002, he was Vice President of Research and Development at WhizBang Labs and Director of its Pittsburgh office.

- In 2002, he joined the faculty at the University of Massachusetts Amherst as a professor of computer science.

- In 2020, he also joined Google as a part-time research scientist.

- McCallum was elected as a fellow of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence in 2009 and as an Association for Computing Machinery in 2017.

- He was the President of International Machine Learning Society from 2014 to 2017.

- He is also the director of the Center for Data Science at UMass and leads a new partnership with the Chan and Zuckerberg Initiative.

- McCallum developed conditional random fields with John D. Lafferty and Fernando Pereira and wrote widely used open-source software toolkits for machine learning, natural language processing, and other text processing.

- He instigated and directs the nonprofit project OpenReview.net, an online platform that aims to promote openness in scientific communication, particularly the peer review process, by providing a flexible cloud-based web interface and underlying database API.

- McCallum's Enron Corpus, a large collection of emails, has been used as a basis for a number of academic studies of social networking and language.
Andrew Ng:
- Andrew Ng is a computer scientist and technology entrepreneur
- He focuses on machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI)
- Ng was a co-founder and head of Google Brain and the former Chief Scientist at Baidu
- He is an adjunct professor at Stanford University and has made substantial contributions to the field of online education as the co-founder of Coursera and deeplearning.ai, teaching over 2.5 million students through his online courses
- Ng has founded Landing AI, which provides AI-powered SaaS products, and launched the AI Fund, a $175-million investment fund for backing AI startups
- He has won numerous awards for his work in AI, robotics, and related fields, and has authored over 300 publications
- Ng is a strong believer in democratizing AI and lowering barriers to entry for businesses and developers. He also supports basic income to allow the unemployed to study AI to re-enter the workforce.
Andrew S. Tanenbaum:
- Andrew Stuart Tanenbaum is an American-Dutch computer scientist and professor emeritus of computer science at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam in the Netherlands.
- He is the author of MINIX, a free Unix-like operating system for teaching purposes, and has written multiple computer science textbooks regarded as standard texts in the field.
- He regards his teaching job as his most important work and has supervised the work of many PhD candidates.
- Tanenbaum has been involved in numerous research projects in the areas of operating systems, distributed systems, and ubiquitous computing.
- He created Electoral-vote.com, a website analyzing opinion polls for the U.S. Presidential Election, using them to project the outcome in the Electoral College.
- Tanenbaum is the architect of the Amsterdam Compiler Kit and wrote a clone of UNIX called MINIX.
- In the Tanenbaum-Torvalds debate, he debated with Linus Torvalds regarding kernel design on Usenet in 1992.
- Tanenbaum has received numerous awards, including Fellow of the ACM, Fellow of the IEEE, and Member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences, and honorary doctorates from Petru Maior University in Romania and Universitatea Politehnica din București. 
- He has been a keynote speaker at several conferences around the world.
Andrew V. Goldberg:
- Andrew Vladislav Goldberg is an American computer scientist.
- He primarily works on design, analysis, and experimental evaluation of algorithms.
- He also worked on mechanism design, computer systems, and complexity theory.
- Goldberg did his undergraduate studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
- He earned a master's degree at the University of California, Berkeley, and finished his doctorate at MIT in 1987.
- He was a faculty member at Stanford University and has worked for various organizations, including NEC Research Institute, Intertrust STAR Laboratories, Microsoft, and Amazon.com.
- Goldberg is best known for his research on graph and network algorithms, including the maximum flow and shortest path problems.
- He also worked on algorithmic game theory and was one of the first scientists to study worst-case mechanism design.
- Goldberg has received numerous awards, including a Hertz Fellowship, A.W. Tucker Prize, NSF Presidential Young Investigator Award, and INFORMS Optimization Society Farkas Prize.
- He is a fellow of the ACM and the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics.
Andrew Viterbi:
- Andrew James Viterbi is an electrical engineer and businessman.
- He co-founded Qualcomm Inc. and invented the Viterbi algorithm.
- He is the Presidential Chair Professor of Electrical Engineering at the University of Southern California's Viterbi School of Engineering.
- He was born in Bergamo, Italy, and immigrated to the United States two years before World War II.
- He attended the Boston Latin School and received both BS and MS in electrical engineering from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
- He carried out PhD studies in digital communications at the University of Southern California, where he graduated in 1963.
- He proposed the Viterbi algorithm to decode convolutionally encoded data in 1967.
- He also helped to develop the Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) standard for cell phone networks.
- He was the co-founder of Linkabit Corporation and Qualcomm Inc.
- He received many awards and honors throughout his career, including the Benjamin Franklin Medal in Electrical Engineering in 2005, the National Medal of Science in 2008, and the IEEE Medal of Honor in 2010.
- He was married to Erna Finci, a Jewish refugee from Sarajevo who was a Shoah survivor, and they had three children.
Andrey Nikolaevich Kolmogorov:
- Andrey Nikolaevich Kolmogorov was a Soviet mathematician born in 1903.
- He made significant contributions to the mathematics of probability theory, topology, intuitionistic logic, turbulence, classical mechanics, algorithmic information theory, and computational complexity.
- Kolmogorov began his studies at Moscow State University in 1920 and gained international recognition in 1922.
- He formed a lifelong friendship with fellow student Pavel Alexandrov and became interested in probability theory.
- In 1933, Kolmogorov published "Foundations of the Theory of Probability," laying the modern axiomatic foundations of probability theory.
- During World War II, Kolmogorov contributed to the Soviet war effort by applying statistical theory to artillery fire.
- Kolmogorov married Anna Dmitrievna Egorova in 1942 and was actively involved in developing pedagogy for gifted children.
- Kolmogorov received numerous awards and honors during and after his lifetime.
- His legacy continues to influence the field of mathematics today.
Andries van Dam:
- Andries "Andy" van Dam is a Dutch-American professor of computer science at Brown University.
- He contributed to the first hypertext system, Hypertext Editing System (HES), along with Ted Nelson.
- He co-authored the popular textbook in computer graphics, Computer Graphics: Principles and Practice.
- Van Dam co-founded the precursor of today's ACM SIGGRAPH conference.
- He mentored several students in hypertext and computer graphics, including Randy Pausch.
- Van Dam helped found the computer science program at Brown and served as its first chair.
- He received his Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Pennsylvania in 1966.
- Van Dam's continued interest in hypertext was crucial to the development of modern markup and browsing technology.
- He serves on several technical boards and committees and has received several awards and recognitions.
- Van Dam demanded that the Brown Center for Information Technology include showers and a Chinese restaurant, and the showers were built.
- The character of Andy in the film Toy Story is named after van Dam, and his book appears on the character's bookshelf.
- A documentary film about van Dam and hypertext, titled "An Educational Experiment in English and Computer Science at Brown University," is available on IMDb and the Internet Archive.
Anil K. Jain (computer scientist, born 1:
- Anil Kumar Jain is a computer scientist and University Distinguished Professor at Michigan State University.
- He is known for his contributions in pattern recognition, computer vision, and biometric recognition.
- He received his PhD from Ohio State University and taught at Wayne State University before joining MSU in 1974.
- Jain has an h-index of 208, which is the highest among computer scientists identified in a survey published by UCLA.
- He has received numerous awards and is a Fellow of ACM, IEEE, AAAS, IAPR, and SPIE.
- Jain has written several books and published numerous research and survey articles in the field of computer science, including on artificial neural networks, data clustering, and biometric recognition.
- He has served on U.S. National Academies panels on Information Technology, Whither Biometrics, and Improvised Explosive Devices.
- Jain was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2016 and the Indian National Academy of Engineering.
- He was also elected as a Foreign Member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2019.
- His research focuses on biometric recognition technologies, including fingerprint and face recognition.
Anita Borg:
- Anita Borg was an American computer scientist known for advocating for women’s representation and professional advancement in technology.
- She founded the Institute for Women and Technology and the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing.
- Borg got her first programming job in 1969 and was awarded a PhD in Computer Science by New York University in 1981.
- Borg spent four years building a fault tolerant Unix-based operating system and developed MECCA, an email and Web-based system for communicating in virtual communities.
- In 1987, Borg founded Systers, the first email network for women in technology and oversaw it until 2000.
- She co-founded the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing in 1994 and founded the Institute for Women and Technology in 1997.
- Borg received several awards and was recognized for her accomplishments as a computer scientist and for her work on behalf of women in computing.
- She was diagnosed with a brain tumor in 1999 and died in 2003.
- Several awards and programs honor Borg's life and work, such as the Google Anita Borg Memorial Scholarship and the UNSW Anita Borg Prize.
Annie Easley:
- Annie Jean Easley was an American computer scientist, mathematician, and rocket scientist.
- She worked for the Lewis Research Center and NASA, and was one of the first African Americans to work at NASA.
- Easley was a leading member of the team which developed software for the Centaur rocket stage.
- She was posthumously inducted into the Glenn Research Hall of Fame in 2015, and in 2021 a crater on the moon was named after her.
- Easley received a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics from Cleveland State University.
- She faced discrimination related to being an African-American during her career, especially when her face was cut out of a photograph at work.
- Easley's work with the Centaur project helped lay the technological foundations for future space shuttle launches.
- She was also an advocate for and encouraged female and minority students to work in STEM careers and tutored young adults who dropped out of school.
- Easley focused on volunteer work after retiring from NASA, becoming an independent contractor in real estate.
- Some of Easley's selected works include Performance and Operational Economics Estimates for a Coal Gasification Combined-Cycle Cogeneration Powerplant and Effect of Turbulent Mixing on Average Fuel Temperatures in a Gas-Core Nuclear Rocket Engine.
Aravind K. Joshi:
- Aravind Krishna Joshi was a professor in the computer science department of the University of Pennsylvania.
- Joshi defined the tree-adjoining grammar formalism used in computational linguistics and natural language processing.
- He received his BE in electrical engineering and DIISc in communication engineering from Pune University and the Indian Institute of Science, respectively.
- Joshi earned his PhD from the electrical engineering department at the University of Pennsylvania in 1960.
- He co-founded and co-directed the Institute for Research in Cognitive Science.
- Joshi received numerous awards and recognition including the Guggenheim fellowship, IEEE fellow, and ACM fellow.
- He was elected to the National Academy of Engineering and awarded the Rumelhart Prize and the Franklin Institute's Benjamin Franklin Medal.
- Joshi was the first recipient of the Association for Computational Linguistics Lifetime Achievement Award.
- He passed away on December 31, 2017.
Arne S\u00f8lvberg:
- Arne Sølvberg is a Norwegian computer scientist and professor in computer science at NTNU in Trondheim.
- He is an expert in the field of information modelling.
- Sølvberg received his MSc in applied physics in 1963 and his PhD in computer science in 1971 from NTNU.
- Between 1963 and 1974, he worked at SINTEF Runnit and led their information systems group.
- In 1974, Sølvberg became the first professor of computer science at NTNU and has been dean of NTNU's Faculty of Information Technology, Mathematics and Electrical Engineering since 2002.
- He has served in various leadership positions in international organizations and co-founded the CAiSE conference series.
- Sølvberg's research interests include information systems design methodology, database design, information modelling, information systems engineering environments, and model-driven design.
- He has published numerous papers and books, including "An Introduction to Information Systems Engineering" and "Information Systems Engineering: State of the Art and Research Themes."
- Sølvberg is a fellow of the Norwegian Academy of Technological Sciences and is married to Ingeborg Sølvberg.
Arvind (computer scientist):
- Arvind is the Johnson Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at MIT.
- He is a Fellow of IEEE and ACM, and a member of the National Academy of Engineering.
- His research includes formal verification of large-scale digital systems and cache coherence protocols for parallel architectures and languages.
- Arvind earned his Bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from IIT Kanpur, and his Master's and PhD in computer science from the University of Minnesota.
- He has co-founded two electronic design automation companies: Sandburst and Bluespec.
- Arvind's current research uses term-rewriting systems for high-level specification and description of architectures and protocols.
- He has authored or co-authored several significant articles and books, including "Implicit parallel programming in pH" with R.S. Nikhil.
- Arvind has received several awards, including the IEEE Computer Society Charles Babbage Award, Distinguished Alumnus Awards from IIT Kanpur and the University of Minnesota, and the Outstanding Achievement Award from the University of Minnesota.
Ashok Goel:
- Ashok K. Goel is a professor of computer science and human-centered computing at Georgia Institute of Technology, and the chief scientist with Georgia Tech's Center for 21st Century Universities.
- He conducts research into cognitive systems at the intersection of artificial intelligence and cognitive science with a focus on computational design and creativity.
- He is the executive director of National Science Foundation's AI Institute for Adult Learning and Online Education and an editor emeritus of AAAI's AI Magazine.
- His research revolves around conceptual design of technical systems and learning about complex systems and systems thinking.
- He has developed computational tools such as the Design by Analogy to Nature Engine for supporting conceptual design.
- He has developed an online course on Knowledge-Based AI and developed Jill Watson, a virtual teaching assistant for automatically answering students’ questions in discussion forums of online classes.
- He has co-edited books on biologically inspired design and blended learning in practice.
- He has received AAAI's Outstanding AI Educator Award and the University System of Georgia Regent's Award for Scholarship of Teaching and Learning.
- His teaching and research have been featured in various media outlets.
Atta ur Rehman Khan:
- Atta ur Rehman Khan is a Pakistani computer scientist and academician.
- He is among the World's Top 2% Scientists according to a Stanford University report.
- He is the founder of National Cyber Crime Forensics Lab Pakistan, which operates in partnership with NR3C.
- He has published numerous research articles and books and is a senior member of IEEE and ACM.
- He received his PhD degree in Computer Science from the University of Malaya.
- As of 2010, he is working as an Associate Professor at the College of Engineering and Information Technology, Ajman University, United Arab Emirates.
- He has experience teaching and researching at seven universities.
- He is an editor and associate editor of several journals.
- He has received numerous honors and awards, such as the Long-Term Research Achievement Award (2023) and the World's Top 2% Scientists award (2022, 2020) from Stanford University.
- He has authored/co-authored/edited several books and numerous research papers on various topics in computer science.
Austin Tate:
- Austin Tate is an Emeritus Professor of Knowledge-based systems at the University of Edinburgh.
- He was the Director of the Artificial Intelligence Applications Institute from 1985 to 2019.
- Tate's research interests are in Artificial Intelligence.
- Some of his selected publications are Generating Project Networks, O-Plan: The open planning architecture, and Task Achieving Agents on the World Wide Web.
- Tate has received various awards such as being elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh and Elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering.
- He was married to Margaret (née Mowbray) in 1975 at Knottingley, West Yorkshire, England.
Avie Tevanian:
- Avadis "Avie" Tevanian is an American software engineer born in 1961.

- He was a principal designer and engineer of the Mach operating system at Carnegie Mellon University.

- Tevanian then designed the NeXTSTEP operating system at NeXT Inc., where he was Vice President of Software Engineering.

- He became senior vice president of software engineering at Apple from 1997 to 2003, and then chief software technology officer from 2003 to 2006.

- At Apple, he redesigned NeXTSTEP to become macOS and iOS, with other operating systems like iPadOS, watchOS, and tvOS stemming from iOS.

- Tevanian was a witness for the United States Department of Justice in United States v. Microsoft in 2001.

- After leaving Apple in 2006, he joined the board of Dolby Labs and Theranos, Inc., but left the board of Theranos in late 2007 under acrimonious circumstances.

- He became Managing Director of Elevation Partners in 2010 and cofounded NextEquity Partners in 2015, where he currently serves as Managing Director.

- Tevanian is of Armenian descent and has a B.A. in mathematics from the University of Rochester and M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University.
Avinash Kak:
- Avinash C. Kak is a professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Purdue University.
- He has conducted research in information processing, with notable contributions in algorithms, languages, and systems related to robotics, computer vision, and networks (including sensor networks).
- His contributions to robotics and computer vision include the development of the 3D-POLY algorithm for recognizing 3D objects in depth maps and the FINALE approach to vision-based navigation by indoor mobile robots.
- Kak's research in image reconstruction algorithms includes the SART algorithm, widely used in CT imaging applications.
- He has authored several books, including Digital Picture Processing (co-authored with Azriel Rosenfeld) and Principles of Computerized Tomographic Imaging.
- Kak has also contributed to the fields of software engineering and open source, developing software modules widely used for data analytics and computer security.
- In addition, he has contributed to computer and network security research, presenting a solution to the problem of botnet detection in computer networks.
- Kak's online lecture notes provide a comprehensive overview of computer and network security.
Azriel Rosenfeld:
- Azriel Rosenfeld was a prominent American Research Professor and Director of the Center for Automation Research at the University of Maryland.
- He had affiliate professorships in the Departments of Computer Science, Electrical Engineering, and Psychology.
- Rosenfeld was a leading researcher in the field of computer image analysis, making fundamental and pioneering contributions to nearly every area of the field.
- His research formed the foundation for a generation of industrial vision inspection systems that have found widespread applications.
- He wrote the first textbook in the field of image analysis (1969), founded the first journal, Computer Graphics and Image Processing (1972), and co-chaired the first international conference (1987).
- Rosenfeld held a Ph.D. in mathematics, rabbinic ordination, and a Doctor of Hebrew Literature degree from Yeshiva University, and honorary degrees from Linkoping University, Oulu University, and Yeshiva University.
- He was awarded an honorary Doctor of Science degree from the Technion (2004, conferred posthumously).
- Rosenfeld was a ba'al koreh (Torah Reader) at Young Israel Shomrai Emunah of Greater Washington.
- The biennial Azriel Rosenfeld Award is given in recognition of an outstanding life-time contribution to the field of image understanding or computer vision.
- He published over 30 books, over 600 book chapters and journal articles, and directed nearly 60 Ph.D. dissertations.
Barbara Engelhardt:
- Barbara Elizabeth Engelhardt is a computer scientist and specialist in bioinformatics.
- She is a Professor at Stanford University and her work focuses on latent variable models, exploratory data analysis for genomic data, and QTLs.
- Engelhardt received a Bachelor of Science and a Master of Science from Stanford University and a PhD from the University of California, Berkeley.
- Engelhardt worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Chicago and later joined Duke University and Princeton University as an assistant professor.
- In 2022, she moved to California and currently holds the position of Professor at Stanford University and Gladstone Institute of Data Science and Biotechnology.
- Engelhardt's research has been funded by the National Institutes of Health through two R01 grants and she has been recognized by several awards including the Overton Prize by the International Society for Computational Biology.
- She has also served on the Board of Directors for Women in Machine Learning and as Diversity & Inclusion Co-chair at the International Conference on Machine Learning.
- Engelhardt's work has been featured in Quanta Magazine and she gave a TEDx talk entitled "Not What but Why: Machine Learning for Understanding Genomics."
Barbara Liskov:
- Barbara Liskov is an American computer scientist.
- She made pioneering contributions to programming languages and distributed computing.
- She developed the Liskov substitution principle which is used in type theory and object-oriented programming.
- Liskov is one of the earliest women to have been granted a doctorate in computer science in the United States.
- She is currently an Institute Professor and Ford Professor of Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
- Liskov has led many significant projects including the Venus operating system, CLU, Argus, and Thor.
- She received the 2008 Turing Award, the highest distinction in computer science, for her work in the design of programming languages and software methodology that led to the development of object-oriented programming.
- Liskov is the author of five books and over one hundred technical papers.
- She is a member of the National Academy of Engineering, the National Academy of Sciences, and a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the Association for Computing Machinery.
- Liskov was recognized as one of the top women faculty members at MIT, and among the top 50 faculty members in the sciences in the U.S.
- She is married to Nathan Liskov and they have one son named Moses.
Barry Boehm:
- Barry William Boehm was an American software engineer and professor of computer science and industrial and systems engineering.
- He was the founding director of the Center for Systems and Software Engineering at the University of Southern California.
- Boehm's contributions to software engineering included the Constructive Cost Model (COCOMO), the spiral model of software development, and the Wideband Delphi method of estimation.
- His research interests included software development process modeling, software requirements engineering, software architectures, software metrics and cost models, software engineering environments, and knowledge-based software engineering.
- He received numerous awards, including the ACM Distinguished Research Award in Software Engineering in 1997 and the IEEE Simon Ramo Medal in 2010.
- Boehm predicted in a 1973 report that software costs would overwhelm hardware costs, inspiring a change in direction in computing.
- He published over 170 articles and several books, including Software Engineering Economics and Balancing Agility and Discipline.
- Honorary degrees were conferred upon Boehm by the U. of Massachusetts in 2000 and by the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2011.
- In 1996, Boehm was elected as a member of the National Academy of Engineering for his contributions to computer and software architectures and models of cost, quality, and risk for aerospace systems.
- Boehm passed away on August 20, 2022.
Beatrice Helen Worsley:
-Beatrice Helen Worsley was a Canadian computer scientist and the first female computer scientist in Canada 

-She received her Ph.D. degree from the University of Cambridge and wrote the first program to run on EDSAC 

-Worsley co-wrote the first compiler for Toronto's Ferranti Mark 1 and taught computers and engineering at Queen's University and the University of Toronto for over 20 years before her death at the age of 50 

-Worsley was born in 1921 in Toronto and excelled in mathematics and science, graduating with the Governor General's Award 

-During World War II, Worsley enlisted in the Women's Royal Canadian Naval Service and eventually studied at MIT for a year 

-After returning to Canada, Worsley worked at the National Research Council of Canada before joining the newly created computing department at the University of Toronto 

-Worsley's contributions to computing include her dissertation on modern computers, the creation of Transcode programming language, and her work on the FERUT computer 

-She was repeatedly passed over for promotions at the University of Toronto and eventually took up a teaching position at Queen's University 

-Worsley received the Lifetime Achievement Award in Computer Science from the Canadian Association of Computer Science in 2014.
Ben Shneiderman:
- Ben Shneiderman is an American computer scientist and a Distinguished University Professor at the University of Maryland Department of Computer Science.
- He is the founding director (1983-2000) of the University of Maryland Human-Computer Interaction Lab.
- Shneiderman is known for his contributions in the field of human-computer interaction, including developing the direct manipulation interface and his eight rules of design.
- He received numerous awards and honors, including being inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
- Shneiderman's major works include "Designing the User Interface: Strategies for Effective Human-Computer Interaction", the treemap concept for hierarchical data visualization, and a taxonomy of interactive dynamics for visual analysis.
- He proposed the research area of universal usability and is currently focusing on the topic of human-centered artificial intelligence.
Bernard Richards:
- Bernard Richards is a British computer scientist and Emeritus Professor of Medical Informatics at the University of Manchester.
- He studied mathematics and physics for his bachelor's degree and worked under the supervision of Alan Turing for his master's degree, helping to validate Turing's theory of morphogenesis.
- Richards changed his research area after Turing's death and worked on studying optics for his doctorate, resulting in a Royal Society paper with his supervisor.
- Later, he worked on hormone peaks in the menstrual cycle and expert systems for open heart surgery and intensive care units.
- Richards has held various positions, including Chairman of the BCS Health Informatics Committee and first President of the Institute for Health Record and Information Management.
- He has also received multiple honors, including being made BCS Fellow of the Year for Services to Medical Informatics and receiving awards from Queen Elizabeth II for contributing to a time capsule during Turing's centenary year.
Bernard de Neumann:
- Frederick Bernard de Neumann (1943-2018) was a British mathematician, computer scientist, inventor, and naval historian.
- He was educated at the Royal Hospital School and Birmingham University.
- Neumann was a Professor of Mathematics at The City University.
- He was a descendant of Johann Andreas von Neumann and Johann Heinrich von Neumann, both of noble birth.
- In 2005, a portrait of Neumann won the Ondaatje Prize from the Royal Society of Portrait Painters.
- The Neumann family is featured in the Genealogisches Handbuch des in Bayern immatrikulierten Adels. 
- The London Mathematical Society Newsletter also featured a prize for a portrait of Neumann in 2005.
Bernhard Sch\u00f6lkopf:
- Bernhard Schölkopf is a German computer scientist born on February 20, 1968.
- He is known for his work in machine learning, especially on kernel methods and causality.
- He is a director at the Max Planck Institute for Intelligent Systems in Tübingen, Germany, where he heads the Department of Empirical Inference.
- Schölkopf is also an affiliated professor at ETH Zürich, honorary professor at the University of Tübingen and the Technical University Berlin, and chairman of the European Laboratory for Learning and Intelligent Systems (ELLIS).
- He developed kernel support vector machine (SVM) methods and introduced kernel principal component analysis (PCA), which led to the foundation of the field of kernel methods.
- Schölkopf also developed methods for causal inference and showed how to exploit underlying causal structures to make machine learning methods more robust with respect to distribution shifts and systematic errors.
- He completed a Diplom in Physics and won the annual award of the German Informatics Association for his PhD thesis defended in 1997.
- He founded the Department for Empirical Inference at the Max Planck Institute for Biological Cybernetics, which grew into a leading center for research in machine learning.
- He is co-editor-in-Chief of the Journal of Machine Learning Research and among the world’s most cited computer scientists.
- Schölkopf’s awards include the Royal Society Milner Award and the BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award in the Information and Communication Technologies category, shared with Isabelle Guyon and Vladimir Vapnik.
Bernhard Thalheim:
- Bernhard Karl Thalheim is a German computer scientist and professor of information systems engineering at the University of Kiel in Kiel, Germany.
- He is known for his work on conceptual modeling and its theoretical foundational contributions.
- Thalheim received his M.Sc. in mathematics and computer science in 1975 at the Dresden University of Technology, his PhD in discrete mathematics in 1979 at the Lomonosov Moscow State University, and his habilitation in theoretical computer science in 1985 at the Dresden University of Technology.
- Thalheim has been a visiting professor at several universities around the world.
- Thalheim has received a number of awards for his achievements in information systems engineering.
- Thalheim's foundational contributions to conceptual modeling theory and science can be found at multiple levels and abstractions.
- His work has been applied in fields such as semantics in databases, co-design of information systems applications, and business process modeling.
- Thalheim has published several books, papers, and articles on various topics in computer science and information systems engineering.
Bert Bos:
- Gijsbert (Bert) Bos is a computer scientist known for the development of Argo, a web browser he developed as a test application for his style sheet proposal.
- Bos studied mathematics at the University of Groningen and wrote his PhD thesis on Rapid user interface development with the script language Gist.
- In 1996, he joined the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) to work on Cascading Style Sheets (CSS).
- Bos is a former chairman and the current W3C Staff Contact of the CSS Working Group.
- He is based in Sophia Antipolis, France.
- Bos, along with Håkon Wium Lie, has written a book about Cascading Style Sheets. The book is titled "Cascading Style Sheets: Designing for the Web" and has three editions with different ISBNs.
- Bos' homepage at W3C is available as an external link.
Bertrand Meyer:
- Bertrand Meyer is a French academic, author and consultant in the field of computer languages.
- He created the Eiffel programming language and the idea of design by contract.
- Meyer received a master's degree in engineering from the École Polytechnique, a second master's degree from Stanford University, and a PhD from the Université de Nancy.
- He was a member of the faculty of the University of California, Santa Barbara and professor of software engineering at ETH Zürich from 2001 to 2016.
- Meyer is known for his contributions, including the concept of Design by Contract, the design of the Eiffel language, and the establishment of the connection between object-oriented programming and software reusability.
- He has received numerous awards and is a member of Academia Europaea and the French Academy of Technologies and a Fellow of the ACM.
- There was a Wikipedia hoax falsely announcing Meyer's death in 2005, which he used to evaluate the resilience of the system.
Betty Holberton:
- Frances Elizabeth Holberton was an American computer scientist and one of the six original programmers of the first general-purpose electronic digital computer, ENIAC.
- Holberton invented breakpoints in computer debugging.
- She studied journalism at the University of Pennsylvania and was hired by the Moore School of Engineering during World War 2 to work as a "computer".
- Holberton helped develop the UNIVAC and was one of those who wrote the first generative programming system (SORT/MERGE). 
- She worked with John Mauchly to develop the C-10 instruction set for BINAC and participated in the development of early standards for the COBOL and FORTRAN programming languages with Grace Hopper.
- Holberton received many awards and was posthumously honored with the Holberton School, a project-based school for software engineers based in San Francisco.
- She died in 2001 of heart disease, diabetes, and complications from a stroke.
- A documentary titled "Top Secret Rosies: The Female 'Computers' of WWII" was released in 2010, featuring interviews with some of the ENIAC programmers.
- The ENIAC team is also the inspiration behind the 2013 documentary, "The Computers," which is part of a series of three.
Bigtable:
- Bigtable is a fully managed NoSQL database service.
- It was developed by Google in 2004 and is used by many Google applications.
- Bigtable scales into the petabyte range and can handle hundreds to thousands of machines.
- It is not a relational database but is a sparse, distributed multi-dimensional sorted map.
- Tables are split into multiple tablets and compressed using the BMDiff and Snappy compression algorithm.
- Bigtable manages over 10 Exabytes of data and serves more than 5 billion requests per second.
- It is available as a part of Google Cloud under the name Cloud Bigtable.
- Bigtable is one of the prototypical examples of a wide-column store.
- Apache HBase and Cassandra are some of the best-known open source projects based on Bigtable.
Bill Gropp:
- William Douglas Gropp is the director of the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA) and the Thomas M. Siebel Chair in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Illinois. 
- He is the founding Director of the Parallel Computing Institute.
- Gropp helped create the Message Passing Interface (MPI) and the Portable, Extensible Toolkit for Scientific Computation (PETSc).
- Gropp has received awards including the Sidney Fernbach Award, the ACM/IEEE-CS Ken Kennedy Award, and an R&D 100 Award for PETSc.
- In 2010, he was elected to the National Academy of Engineering and received the IEEE TCSC Medal for Excellence in Scalable Computing.
- Gropp received his PhD at Stanford in 1982 under Joseph Oliger.
- He is a Fellow of ACM, IEEE, and SIAM, and an elected member of the National Academy of Engineering.
Bill Joy:
- William Nelson Joy is an American computer engineer and venture capitalist
- He co-founded Sun Microsystems in 1982 and served as Chief Scientist and CTO at the company until 2003
- He played a key role in the development of BSD UNIX and was the original author of the vi text editor
- Joy was elected a member of the National Academy of Engineering in 1999
- He co-founded venture capital firm HighBAR Ventures in 1999, and joined Kleiner Perkins in 2005
- In 2000, he wrote an essay titled "Why The Future Doesn't Need Us," expressing concerns over the risks of technological developments in genetics, nanotechnology, and robotics
- Despite his concerns, Joy is a venture capitalist investing in GNR technology
- Joy is credited with establishing "Joy's law," stating that most of the smartest people work for someone else, and that companies should hire the best employees
- Joy also devised a formula in 1983 called Joy's law, stating that peak computer speed doubles each year, expressed in MIPS
Bjarne Stroustrup:
- Bjarne Stroustrup is a Danish computer scientist.
- He is most notable for inventing and developing the C++ programming language.
- He attended Aarhus University and graduated with a master's degree in mathematics and computer science.
- He received a PhD in computer science from the University of Cambridge, where he studied communication in distributed computer systems.
- He began his career as a member of technical staff at Bell Labs in 1979 and developed C++ there.
- He has held various positions, including the head of AT&T Bell Labs' Large-scale Programming Research department and the College of Engineering Chair Professor in Computer Science at Texas A&M University.
- As of July 2022, Stroustrup is a professor of Computer Science at Columbia University.
- Stroustrup has written books and published over 100 academic articles on C++.
- He has received numerous awards and honors, including The Charles Stark Draper Prize from The US National Academy of Engineering in 2018 for conceptualizing and developing the C++ programming language.
- Stroustrup is a founding member of the C++ standards committee and has remained an active member ever since.
Bonnie Nardi:
- Bonnie Nardi is an emeritus professor at the University of California, Irvine and led the TechDec research lab in Human-Computer Interaction and computer-supported cooperative work.
- Her work includes research on activity theory, interaction design, games, social media, and society and technology.
- Nardi has worked for high-tech companies such as AT&T Labs, Agilent, Hewlett-Packard and Apple labs to examine consumers' behavior.
- She has published several books on activity theory and interaction design, including "Acting with Technology" and "Activity Theory in HCI".
- Nardi's research interests focus on human-computer interaction, computer-supported cooperative work, activity theory, computer-mediated communication, and interaction design.
- She is widely known for her work on information ecologies, especially Chapter 7 of her book "Information Ecologies", which focused on librarians as keystone species.
- Nardi holds a PhD from the School of Social Sciences at University of California, Irvine, and her self-described theoretical orientation is "activity theory".
- She is currently conducting an ethnographic study of World of Warcraft.
- Nardi has authored several papers published in academic journals, such as "NetWORKers and their activity in intensional networks" and "Why We Blog".
- Her work has influenced digital anthropology, digital libraries, and other fields in computer science.
- She was elected to the ACM CHI academy in 2013 and retired in 2018.
Brian Cantwell Smith:
- Brian Cantwell Smith is a philosopher and cognitive scientist.
- He works in the fields of cognitive science, computer science, information studies, and philosophy.
- Smith's research focuses on the foundations and philosophy of computing and computational metaphors in other fields.
- He is currently a professor at the University of Toronto.
- Smith received his BS, MS, and PhD degrees from MIT.
- His doctoral dissertation introduced the notion of computational reflection in programming languages.
- He was a founder of the Center for the Study of Language and Information at Stanford University.
- Smith has published more than 35 articles and three books.
- One of his books is called On the Origin of Objects.
- He previously held a Canada Research Chair in the Foundations of Information.
- Smith is cross-appointed as Professor in the departments of Philosophy and Computer Science and in the Program in Communication, Culture and Technology at University of Toronto at Mississauga.
- His father was the scholar of religion Wilfred Cantwell Smith.
Brian Kernighan:
- Brian Wilson Kernighan is a Canadian computer scientist.
- He contributed to the development of Unix alongside Unix creators Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie while working at Bell Labs.
- Kernighan is the co-author of the first book on the C programming language with Dennis Ritchie.
- He authored many Unix programs, including ditroff, and is the co-author of the AWK and AMPL programming languages.
- Kernighan and Shen Lin devised famous heuristics for two NP-complete optimization problems: graph partitioning and the travelling salesman problem, known as the Kernighan–Lin algorithm and the Lin–Kernighan heuristic respectively.
- Kernighan has been a Professor of Computer Science at Princeton University since 2000 and is the Director of Undergraduate Studies in the Department of Computer Science.
- In 2015, he co-authored the book The Go Programming Language.
- Kernighan is the author of many books and reports, including The C Programming Language, The Practice of Programming, and The Unix Programming Environment.
- He wrote a famous criticism of Niklaus Wirth's Pascal titled "Why Pascal is Not My Favorite Programming Language".
- Kernighan is the author of several algorithms, including the first documented "Hello, world!" program, ditroff, eqn, Ratfor, m4, AWK, AMPL, and pic.
- Kernighan uses a 13-inch MacBook Air as his primary device and uses Sam as his text editor.
Bruce Arden:
- Bruce Wesley Arden was an American computer scientist who lived from 1927 to 2021.
- He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II as a Radar Technician Third Class.
- Arden graduated from Purdue University in 1949 with a BS(EE) and began his computing career in 1950 at the Allison Division of General Motors.
- He co-authored two compilers and was involved in the initial design of the Michigan Terminal System (MTS) time-sharing operating system while working at the University of Michigan.
- Arden completed his doctoral program in electrical engineering in 1965 and became a professor and chairman of the Computer and Communication Sciences department at the University of Michigan.
- He later accepted a professorship at Princeton University and then became the Dean of the College of Engineering and Applied Science at the University of Rochester.
- Arden wrote two books on numerical computation and supervised many students in their studies of computing.
- He retired in 1995 and lived in Michigan and Maine.
Bruce Schneier:
- Bruce Schneier is an American cryptographer, computer security professional, privacy specialist, and writer.
- He is a lecturer in public policy at the Harvard Kennedy School and a fellow at the Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society.
- Schneier is a board member of the Electronic Frontier Foundation and an advisory board member of several other organizations.
- He has authored several books on general security topics, computer security, and cryptography.
- Schneier also writes a monthly internet newsletter and maintains a security weblog.
- He is frequently quoted in the press on security and cryptography issues.
- Schneier has been involved in the development of several cryptographic algorithms.
- He is critical of digital rights management and is a proponent of full disclosure in security issues.
- Schneier has advocated for spending homeland security money on intelligence, investigation, and emergency response.
- He coined the term "movie-plot threat" to describe dramatic terrorist attack scenarios and is a critic of security measures that protect against them.
- Schneier believes that designing systems to fail well is more important than trying to prevent all malicious incursions.
Bryan Cantrill:
- Bryan M. Cantrill is an American software engineer.
- He worked at Sun Microsystems and later at Oracle Corporation after its acquisition of Sun.
- He left Oracle in 2010 to become Vice President of Engineering at Joyent, later transitioning to Chief Technology Officer in 2014 until his departure in 2019.
- Cantrill is now the CTO of Oxide Computer company.
- He is known for his development of DTrace, a function of the OS Solaris 10 for tracing and diagnosis of software.
- Cantrill was named one of the 35 Top Young Innovators by Technology Review in 2005.
- He was a member of the ACM Queue Editorial Board.
- Cantrill was involved in the founding of Fishworks, a project at Sun Microsystems that produced the Sun Storage 7000 Unified Storage Systems.
- In a 1996 technical discussion, Cantrill made a controversial comment to Linux kernel developer David S. Miller that later caused regret.
- In 2010, Cantrill compared Oracle's behavior to that of Nazis after leaving the company.
- Cantrill has expressed a preference for permissive open source software licenses over copyleft licenses.
Butler Lampson:
- Butler W. Lampson is an American computer scientist known for his contributions to distributed personal computing.
- His early education includes an A.B. in physics from Harvard University and a PhD in electrical engineering and computer science from the University of California, Berkeley.
- Lampson was one of the founding members of Xerox PARC, where he worked as a principal scientist and senior research fellow, and helped design the Xerox Alto, the first personal computer with a graphical user interface (GUI).
- Lampson also worked on many other influential technologies at PARC, such as laser printer design, Ethernet, and the Bravo program.
- He later worked for Digital Equipment Corporation and Microsoft Research.
- Lampson has received numerous honors and awards throughout his career, including the ACM Turing Award, the IEEE John von Neumann Medal, and the Charles Stark Draper Prize.
- He is often quoted as saying, "Any problem in computer science can be solved with another level of indirection".
- Lampson's website and an oral history interview with him are available online.
B\u00f6rje Langefors:
- Börje Langefors was a Swedish engineer and computer scientist, and Emeritus Professor of Business Information Systems at the Department of Computer and Systems Science, Stockholm University and Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm.
- He was born in Ystad, Sweden in 1915 and received his training from the Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm.
- Langefors was a key player in founding the IFIP TC8 Technical Committee of Information Systems in 1976.
- A major achievement of his work is the formulation of the 'infological equation' describing the difference between data and information.
- Langefors published numerous papers in journals, books, and archival proceedings since the 1970s.
- An annual award titled Börje Langeforspriset has been announced by the Swedish Information Systems Academy since 2011 for the best doctoral dissertation in Sweden.
C. A. R. Hoare:
- Sir Charles Antony Richard Hoare is a British computer scientist.
- He has made contributions to programming languages, algorithms, operating systems, formal verification, and concurrent computing.
- He developed the quicksort sorting algorithm and Hoare logic for verifying program correctness.
- He introduced the CSP language for specifying interactions between concurrent processes and formulated the dining philosophers problem with Edsger Dijkstra.
- He is credited with inventing and later criticizing the null pointer.
- Since 1977, he has held positions at the University of Oxford and Microsoft Research in Cambridge.
- Hoare's work earned him the Turing Award in 1980.
- He has written several books, including Structured Programming and Communicating Sequential Processes.
- Hoare is an Emeritus Professor at the University of Oxford and a principal researcher at Microsoft Research in Cambridge.
- He is married to Jill Pym.
C. J. van Rijsbergen:
- C. J. "Keith" van Rijsbergen is a professor of computer science at the University of Glasgow.
- He is one of the pioneers of modern Information Retrieval.
- He was born in Rotterdam and educated in multiple countries including Australia and the Netherlands.
- He holds a degree in mathematics from the University of Western Australia and a PhD in computer science from the University of Cambridge.
- He has held positions at Monash University, University College Dublin and Glasgow University.
- He is the founder of the Glasgow Information Retrieval Group.
- He is the author of two notable books: Information Retrieval and The Geometry of Information Retrieval.
- He has received several awards and honors including being inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery, being awarded the Tony Kent Strix award and the Gerard Salton Award for Quantum haystacks.
- He chaired the Scientific Board of the Information Retrieval Facility from 2007 to 2012.
Carl Hewitt:
- Carl Eddie Hewitt was an American computer scientist.
- He designed the Planner programming language for automated planning and the actor model of concurrent computation.
- Planner was the first programming language based on procedural plans invoked using pattern-directed invocation from assertions and goals.
- The actor model influenced the development of the Scheme programming language, the π-calculus, and served as an inspiration for several other programming languages.
- Hewitt obtained his PhD in mathematics at MIT in 1971.
- He was a faculty member of the MIT Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science and became emeritus in 2000.
- Hewitt's work on inconsistency robustness provided practical rigorous foundations for systems dealing with pervasively inconsistent information.
- Planner introduced the notion of the "procedural embedding of knowledge", an alternative to the logical approach to knowledge encoding for artificial intelligence pioneered by John McCarthy.
- The actor model of computation was introduced in a 1973 paper authored by Hewitt, Peter Bishop, and Richard Steiger and has been a focus of Hewitt's work for over 30 years.
- A number of programming languages were developed to specifically implement the actor model, such as ACT-1, SALSA, Caltrop, E, and ActorScript.
- Hewitt's selected works include PLANNER: A Language for Proving Theorems in Robots IJCAI'69 and The Scientific Community Metaphor IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics.
Carl Sassenrath:
- Carl Sassenrath is an architect of operating systems and computer languages
- He brought multitasking to personal computers in 1985 with the creation of the Amiga Computer operating system kernel
- He is the designer of the REBOL computer language, REBOL/IOS collaboration environment, the Safeworlds AltME private messaging system, and other products
- Carl is currently a Principal Engineer at Roku, Inc.
- He was born in California in 1957 and his family relocated to a small town of Eureka, California in the late 1960s
- From his early childhood, he was actively involved in electronics, amateur radio, photography, and filmmaking
- He graduated from the University of California, Davis in 1980 with a B.S. in EECS
- During his time at Hewlett-Packard, he became interested in minimizing the high complexity found in most operating systems of that time and proposed his own concepts of a microkernel-based OS
- In 1983, he joined Amiga Computer, Inc. and created a preemptive multitasking operating system within a microkernel design for the Amiga
- In 1986, he was recruited to Apple Computer's Advanced Technology Group (ATG) to invent the next generation of operating systems
- In 1996, he created REBOL, the relative expression-based object language, and founded REBOL Technologies in 1998
- He currently lives in Ukiah, California and is interested in amateur radio, video production, quantum electrodynamics, and boating
- He volunteers with the Television Improvement Association, a community organization that brings free, over-the-air television broadcasts into the Ukiah area.
Carol Spradling:
- Carol Spradling is an American professor and computer scientist.
- She served as the first Director of the School of Computer Science and Information Systems at Northwest Missouri State University.
