- He is perhaps best known for his work on the Secure Digital Music Initiative (SDMI) challenge to break digital audio watermark technologies.
- Felten, with help from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, sued SDMI and other copyright holders, requesting a declaratory judgment ruling that the publication of their scientific paper would be legal.
- He discovered security flaws in a Diebold Election Systems voting machine and Sequoia Advantage voting machines.
- In February 2008, Felten was part of the team that discovered the cold boot attack, which allows someone with physical access to a computer to bypass operating system protections.
- Felten was named the first Chief Technologist of the Federal Trade Commission in 2010.
Edward H. Shortliffe:
- Edward ("Ted") Hance Shortliffe is a Canadian-born American biomedical informatician, physician, and computer scientist.
- He is a pioneer in the use of artificial intelligence in medicine, and was the principal developer of the clinical expert system MYCIN, a rule-based artificial intelligence expert system.
- He is regarded as a founder of the field of biomedical informatics, and received the Morris F. Collen Award from the American College of Medical Informatics in 2006.
- He has held administrative positions in academic medicine, research and national bodies including the Institute of Medicine, American College of Physicians, National Science Foundation, National Institutes of Health, and National Library of Medicine.
- In March 2007, he became founding dean of the University of Arizona's College of Medicine - Phoenix campus, and in July 2009, he assumed a position as president and chief executive officer of the American Medical Informatics Association.
- He has authored over 300 publications and 7 books on the topic of biomedical informatics.
- He has been honored with awards like the Grace Murray Hopper Award, Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation Faculty Scholar in General Internal Medicine, and the Young Investigator Award from the Western Society for Clinical Investigation.
Edward Yourdon:
- Edward Nash Yourdon was an American software engineer, computer consultant, author and lecturer, and software engineering methodology pioneer
- He was one of the lead developers of the structured analysis techniques of the 1970s and co-developed Yourdon/Whitehead and Coad/Yourdon methodologies for object-oriented analysis/design
- Yourdon founded the consulting firm Yourdon Inc. in 1974 and sold it in 1986
- He predicted that the Y2K bug could lead to collapse of civilization, which did not materialize at the scale predicted and caused him to lose credibility with some in the software industry
- Yourdon authored over 550 technical articles and 26 computer books since 1967, including "Decline and Fall of the American Programmer", "Object-Oriented Systems Development: An Integrated Approach", and "Death March: The Complete Software Developer's Guide to Surviving 'Mission Impossible' Projects"
Edwin Catmull:
-Edwin Catmull is an American computer scientist who co-founded Pixar and was the President of Walt Disney Animation Studios.

-He is known for his contributions to 3D computer graphics and was honored with the 2019 ACM Turing Award.

-As a student, Catmull discovered texture mapping and bicubic patches and invented algorithms for spatial anti-aliasing and refining subdivision surfaces.

-In 1972, he made his earliest contribution to the film industry, creating a one-minute animated version of his left hand.

-He worked for Applicon and the New York Institute of Technology before being recruited by George Lucas to bring computer graphics, video editing, and digital audio into the entertainment field.

-He became Vice President at Industrial Light & Magic computer graphics division at Lucasfilm in 1979.

-In 1986, Steve Jobs bought Lucasfilm's digital division and founded Pixar, where Catmull would work.

-He was implicated in the High-Tech Employee Antitrust scandal while at Pixar.

-He received several awards for his contributions to computer graphics and filmmaking, including the Gordon E. Sawyer Award and the 2019 Turing Award.

-Catmull's book, "Creativity, Inc.: Overcoming the Unseen Forces That Stand in the Way of True Inspiration," was shortlisted for the Financial Times and Goldman Sachs Business Book of the Year Award.
Edwin E. Tozer:
- Edwin Ellis (Ed) Tozer is a retired British management and IT consultant and SF author.
- He started his career in the manufacturing and mining industry before becoming a junior systems analyst at Scicon in London in 1969.
- In 1984, he founded Edwin E. Tozer Limited, which specialized in data management study and dissolved after his retirement in 2008.
- Tozer is known for his early work on business information systems in the 1970s and 1980s.
- He wrote several books, including "Application Development Tools" (1984), "Planning for Effective Business Information Systems" (1988), and "Strategic Is/It Planning" (1996).
- Tozer was one of the first to propose the concept of business architecture in the field of business information systems planning.
- His model for developing information systems consisted of four phases: determining business information needs, developing conceptual architecture for systems and data, determining key priorities and system groupings, and migration planning.
- Tozer also wrote science fiction, including "Morphosis" (2010), where he speculated on the evolution of mankind as a species.
Eiiti Wada:
- Eiiti Wada is a computer scientist and emeritus professor at the University of Tokyo.
- He is the Research Director of Internet Initiative Japan (IIJ), a computer network technology company.
- Wada is one of the creators of the Happy Hacking Keyboard.
- In 1968, he was a member of the design team for a Japanese candidate language named ALGOL N, which was not chosen for ALGOL 68.
- He became a member of IFIP WG2.1 in 1972, which specified, maintains, and supports ALGOL 60 and 68.
- He was a member of the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and contributed to character encoding set standards.
- Wada helped create related Japanese Industrial Standards (JIS) X 0208, 0212.
- As of 2020, he works on computer graphics for the IIJ Innovation Institute.
Eldon C. Hall:
- Eldon Hall led hardware design for the Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC) at MIT
- He advocated for the use of integrated circuits in the AGC
- Hall wrote extensively about the development of the AGC, culminating in his book Journey to the Moon
- He pursued undergraduate education at Eastern Nazarene College, graduate education at Boston University, and a doctoral degree at Harvard University (although he did not complete the PhD)
- Hall also wrote an autobiography titled From the Farm to Pioneering with Digital Computers
- References are included in the article.
Emil Post:
- Emil Leon Post was an American mathematician and logician born in Poland in 1897.
- He is best known for his work in computability theory and developing a mathematical model of computation similar to Alan Turing's.
- Post proved that the propositional calculus of Principia Mathematica was complete in his doctoral thesis and also independently discovered truth tables.
- He made important contributions to the theory of polyadic groups and demonstrated that a polyadic group operation on a set can be expressed in terms of a group operation on the same set.
- Post introduced correspondence systems in 1946 to give examples of undecidability, and the Post Correspondence Problem he introduced turned out to be exactly what was needed to obtain undecidability results in the theory of formal languages.
- Post's problem, which he raised in 1944, stimulated much research and was later solved in the affirmative in the 1950s.
- Post died in 1954 at the age of 57 following electroshock treatment for depression.
Eric Hehner:
- Eric "Rick" C. R. Hehner is a Canadian computer scientist born in Ottawa on September 16, 1947.
- He holds a Bachelor of Science (B.Sc.) in Mathematics and Physics from Carleton University, and a Master of Science (M.Sc.) and a Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) in Computer Science from the University of Toronto.
- He joined the faculty at the University of Toronto, becoming a full professor in 1983 and retiring in 2012.
- Hehner's main research area is formal methods of software design which can apply to different types of programs, including sequential, parallel, terminating, and nonterminating ones.
- He is the inventor of quote notation, a representation of rational numbers that allows easier arithmetic and avoids roundoff error.
- He was involved in the development of international standards in programming and informatics as a member of International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP) working groups on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi, and on Programming Methodology.
- Hehner's other research areas include probabilistic programming, unified algebra, and high-level circuit design.
- He has published several articles and a book called "A Practical Theory of Programming," which is available for free in PDF format.
- His archival papers are held at the University of Toronto Archives and Records Management Services.
Erik Demaine:
- Erik D. Demaine is a professor of computer science at MIT and a former child prodigy
- He was homeschooled and started university at the age of 12, completing his bachelor's degree at 14 and his PhD at 20
- His PhD work focused on computational origami and earned him several awards
- Demaine is part of the Theory of Computation group at MIT
- He creates mathematical origami with his father Martin Demaine, which has been exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art and the Smithsonian Museum
- In 2001, he co-edited a tribute book for Martin Gardner with his father and Gathering 4 Gardner founder Tom M. Rodgers
- Demaine has received numerous awards, including the MacArthur Fellowship, EATCS Presburger Award, and Nerode Prize
- He is a fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery and has been awarded an honorary doctorate by Bard College
- External links include his MIT News biography and publications indexed by Google Scholar.
Eugene Luks:
- Eugene Michael Luks is an American mathematician and computer scientist.
- He is a professor emeritus of computer and information science at the University of Oregon.
- Luks is known for his research on the graph isomorphism problem and on algorithms for computational group theory.
- He earned his undergraduate degree at the City College of New York and his doctorate in mathematics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
- Luks taught at Tufts University and Bucknell University before joining the University of Oregon faculty.
- In 1985, he won the Fulkerson Prize for his work on graph isomorphism.
- In 2012, he became a fellow of the American Mathematical Society.
- His notable publications include "Polynomial-time algorithms for permutation groups", "Isomorphism of graphs of bounded valence can be tested in polynomial time", and "Canonical labeling of graphs".
Fernando J. Corbat\u00f3:
- Fernando José "Corby" Corbató was a prominent American computer scientist.
- He was notable as a pioneer in the development of time-sharing operating systems.
- Corbató was born on July 1, 1926, in Oakland, California.
- He earned a PhD in physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1956.
- The first time-sharing system he was associated with was known as the MIT Compatible Time-Sharing System (CTSS).
- He is credited with the first use of passwords to secure access to files on a large computer system.
- Corbató received the Turing Award in 1990.
- He died on July 12, 2019, in Newburyport, Massachusetts, at the age of 93 due to complications from diabetes.
Frances E. Allen:
- Frances Elizabeth Allen was an American computer scientist and pioneer in the field of optimizing compilers.
- Allen was the first woman to become an IBM Fellow, and in 2006 became the first woman to win the Turing Award.
- Her achievements include seminal work in compilers, program optimization, and parallelization.
- Allen worked for IBM from 1957 to 2002 and subsequently was a Fellow Emerita.
- Allen grew up on a farm in Peru, New York, near Lake Champlain, as the oldest of six children.
- She graduated from The New York State College for Teachers with a Bachelor of Science degree in mathematics in 1954 and earned a Master of Science degree in mathematics in 1957.
- Her papers on program optimization were fundamental in the field of optimizing compilers, and her contributions had a significant impact on compiler research and practice.
- Allen was a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) and the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM).
- In addition to the Turing Award, Allen received various honors and awards, including the IEEE Computer Society Charles Babbage Award and the Computer Pioneer Award.
- Allen died on August 4, 2020, on her 88th birthday, from complications with Alzheimer's disease.
Franco Preparata:
- Franco P. Preparata is a computer scientist and the An Wang Professor Emeritus of Computer Science at Brown University.
- He authored the book "Computational Geometry: An Introduction" in 1985, which became the standard textbook in the field and was translated into four languages.
- Preparata has made significant contributions to computational geometry, including the notion of "algorithmic degree" for controlling geometric algorithms.
- He worked in coding theory, parallel computation, and VLSI theory, publishing several papers that received awards.
- Preparata's recent research has focused on computational biology, including a novel approach to DNA sequencing by hybridization.
- He received his doctorate from the University of Rome in 1959 and has published nearly 250 articles and three books.
- Preparata is an IEEE and ACM Fellow and was awarded an honorary doctorate from the University of Padova in 1997.
- He advises many Ph.D. students and is well respected in the field of computer science.
Frank Harary:
- Frank Harary was an American mathematician specializing in graph theory.
- He was known as one of the "fathers" of modern graph theory, standardizing its terminology and broadening its reach to include fields like physics, psychology, sociology, and anthropology.
- Harary was a skilled communicator and often turned theorems into games or puzzles to challenge and entertain his audience at various levels of mathematical proficiency.
- He earned his Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley, and taught at the University of Michigan before becoming a Distinguished Professor at New Mexico State University.
- He authored multiple books on graph theory, published over 800 papers, and became famous for his work on graph enumeration and signed graphs.
- Harary also played a role in improving the DeGroot learning model in behavioral economics, and developed a method for detecting cliques in social networks.
- One of Harary's notable contributions is the study of the "tree square root" of a graph and how to determine if a graph is derived from it.
- Harary received several honors and awards for his work and contributions, including becoming an honorary lifetime member of the Calcutta Mathematical Society and the South African Mathematical Society.
- He passed away in 2005, leaving behind an extensive bibliography of scholarly articles and books.
Fran\u00e7ois Vernadat:
- François B. Vernadat is a French and Canadian computer scientist specializing in enterprise architectures, business process modeling, information systems design and analysis, systems integration and interoperability, and systems analysis using Petri nets.
- He received a master's degree in Electronics and Automatic Control and a PhD in 1981 from the University of Clermont, France.
- He has been a research officer at the National Research Council of Canada and at Institut National de Recherche en Informatique et Automatique (INRIA), France.
- He has been a professor at the University of Metz in automatic control and industrial engineering and is currently the head of the IT Infrastructure department of the European Court of Auditors.
- He has authored over 280 scientific papers in journals, conferences, and edited books and is an associate editor for "Computers in Industry," "International Journal of Production Research," and "Computers & Industrial Engineering," among others.
- His research work has been dealing with enterprise architectures, enterprise engineering, enterprise modeling, enterprise integration, information systems design and analysis, and various aspects of industrial engineering such as facility layout, performance management, cost estimation, and competency modeling.
- Some of his notable publications include "Enterprise Modeling and Integration: Principles and Applications," "The CIMOSA Languages," and "Interoperable Enterprise Systems: Principles, Concepts, and Methods."
Fred B. Schneider:
- Frederick William Schneider III is an American singer, songwriter, arranger, and musician.

- He is the frontman of the rock band the B-52's, of which he is a founding member.

- Schneider is well known for his sprechgesang, which he developed from reciting poetry over guitars.

- He was born in Newark, New Jersey in 1951 and lived in Oceanport, New Jersey after moving there from Belleville, New Jersey.

- Schneider attended the University of Georgia where he wrote a book of poetry for a class project.

- The B-52's got their start in 1976 when founders Cindy Wilson, Ricky Wilson, Kate Pierson, Keith Strickland, and Schneider played an impromptu number after drinking at a Chinese restaurant in Athens, Georgia.

- After the death of Ricky Wilson in 1985, the band went on hiatus but reformed in 1989 and went on to mainstream success.

- Apart from B-52's, Schneider has released two solo albums and worked on a side project called the Superions.

- Until late 2008, Schneider hosted a show called Party Out of Bounds.

- Schneider's personal life includes being a lifelong vegetarian and coming out as gay to his mother.

- He has appeared in films and TV shows and has also written a few books.
Frieder Nake:
- Frieder Nake is a mathematician, computer scientist, and pioneer of computer art.

- He is known internationally for his contributions to the earliest manifestations of computer art.

- Nake had his first exhibition at Galerie Wendelin Niedlich in Stuttgart in November 1965.

- Until 1969, Nake generated about 300 to 400 works that he showed in many exhibitions.

- Nake participated in important group shows of the 1960s, such as Cybernetic Serendipity.

- In 1971, he wrote a provocative note for Page, the Bulletin of the Computer Arts Society.

- His book "Ästhetik als Informationsverarbeitung" (1974) is one of the first to study connections between aesthetics, computing, and information theory.

- He has been a professor of interactive computer graphics at the Department of Computer Science at Bremen since 1972.

- He won the First Prize of the Computer Art Contest of Computers & Automation in 1966.

- Nake's work is represented in public collections worldwide, including the Tate Gallery in London and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Zagreb.
Friedrich L. Bauer:
- Friedrich Ludwig "Fritz" Bauer was a German pioneer of computer science and professor at the Technical University of Munich.
- He studied mathematics and theoretical physics at Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität in Munich.
- Bauer was involved in constructing computing machinery and proposed the widely used stack method of expression evaluation.
- He was a member of committees that developed imperative computer programming languages ALGOL 58 and its successor ALGOL 60.
- Bauer was an influential figure in establishing computer science as an independent subject in German universities.
- He coined the term software engineering and defined it as the "Establishment and use of sound engineering principles to economically obtain software that is reliable and works on real machines efficiently."
- Bauer's scientific contributions also spread from numerical analysis and fundamentals of interpretation and translation of programming languages to program transformation methods and systems.
- Bauer was the doctoral advisor of 39 students.
- He was one of the 19 founding members of the German Informatics Society and editor of the Informatik Spektrum.
- Bauer received numerous awards and honorary doctorates.
- The Technical University of Munich awards the Friedrich L. Bauer Prize in computer science in his honor.
- Bauer's publications include papers on compilers, the introduction to ALGOL, and books on cryptology.
G.M. Nijssen:
- Gerardus Maria "Sjir" Nijssen is a Dutch computer scientist, former professor of computer science at the University of Queensland, consultant, and author.


- Nijssen is considered the founder of verbalization in computer science, and one of the founders of business modeling and information analysis based on natural language.


- Nijssen finished his study at the Eindhoven University of Technology in 1965, and started working at Philips at the department of Commercial Efficiency Research.


- In 1970 he moved to the Control Data Corporation, a pioneer in the field of computer science with the European headquarters in Brussels in Belgium. In those years he started fact-based modeling and developed NIAM.


- During the period of 1982 to 1989 Nijssen was a full-time professor of Computer science at the University of Queensland in Brisbane, Australia, where he worked together with Terry Halpin amongst others in further developing NIAM.


- When returning to the Netherlands in 1989, he founded PNA Group and accepted a position at the University of Maastricht, Netherlands.


- Nijssen published more than 50 articles and 7 books.


- Nijssen's notable published work includes "Conceptual Schema and Relational Database Design: a fact oriented approach" and "CogNIAM".


- Nijssen developed Cognition enhanced Natural language Information Analysis Method (CogNIAM) focused entirely on the most productive protocol for the development of business requirements and integrated business modeling.
Gary William Flake:
- Gary William Flake is a computer scientist and author.
- He received his bachelor's degree from Clemson University and his PhD from the University of Maryland.
- Flake has published works related to machine-learning, data-mining, and self-organization.
- He worked at NEC Research Institute, Overture, Yahoo! Research Labs, and Microsoft Live Labs before founding Clipboard in 2011.
- Salesforce acquired Clipboard in 2013, and Flake became the CTO for Search.
- Flake has served on academic conference committees and is a member of the editorial board for the ACM's Transactions on Internet Technologies.
Gast\u00f3n Gonnet:
- Gaston H. Gonnet is a computer scientist and entrepreneur from Uruguay.
- He received his doctorate in computer science from the University of Waterloo in 1977.
- Gonnet co-founded the Symbolic Computation Group at the University of Waterloo in 1980.
- He also co-founded Waterloo Maple Inc. in 1988 to sell the Maple system commercially.
- Gonnet co-founded the New Oxford English Dictionary project in 1984, which led to the creation of a digital version of the Oxford English Dictionary.
- Gonnet is a computer science professor at ETH Zurich in Switzerland and has developed the Darwin programming language and OMA package for gene orthology prediction.
- He is the chief scientist of Canadian startups CeeqIT and Porfiau.
- On June 9, 2011, Gonnet and Keith O. Geddes received the ACM Richard D. Jenks Memorial Prize for Excellence in Software Engineering Applied to Computer Algebra for the Maple Project.
- Gonnet was awarded a Dr. Honoris Causa by the Universidad de la República, engineering faculty from Uruguay on March, 14 2013.
Gene Amdahl:
- Gene Myron Amdahl was an American computer architect and high-tech entrepreneur
- He was born to immigrant parents of Norwegian and Swedish descent in Flandreau, South Dakota
- He completed a degree in engineering physics at South Dakota State University in 1948
- He worked on the IBM mainframe computers, including the IBM 704, IBM 709, and the Stretch project, which was the basis for the IBM 7030
- He formulated Amdahl's law, which states a fundamental limitation of parallel computing
- He left IBM in 1970 and set up Amdahl Corporation in Sunnyvale, California, which manufactured "plug-compatible" mainframes and sold over US$1 billion of V6 and V7 mainframes by 1979
- He left Amdahl Corporation in 1979 and set up Trilogy Systems, Commercial Data Servers, and Andor International, but all faced various challenges and eventually failed
- He co-founded Xbridge Systems, which builds software to scan mainframe datasets for sensitive information, and was appointed to the board of advisors of Massively Parallel Technologies in 2004
- Amdahl received numerous awards and patents to his credit and has received Honorary Doctorates from his alma maters and two other institutions
- He died on November 10, 2015, in Palo Alto, California, from pneumonia, six days shy of his 93rd birthday.
Gene Golub:
- Gene Howard Golub was an American numerical analyst and professor.
- He taught at Stanford University and advised over 30 doctoral students.
- Golub was pivotal in creating the NA-Net and the NA-Digest, as well as the International Congress on Industrial and Applied Mathematics.
- He contributed to algorithms for matrix decompositions, including publishing an algorithm for singular value decomposition (SVD) in 1970 that is still used today.
- Golub was recognized for his work with various awards and memberships to national academies.
- He authored many articles and several books, including "Matrix Computations" co-authored with Charles F. Van Loan.
- Golub passed away in 2007 from acute myeloid leukemia.
Geoffrey Hinton:
- Geoffrey Hinton is a British-Canadian cognitive psychologist and computer scientist, known for his work on artificial neural networks.
- He works for Google Brain and the University of Toronto.
- Hinton co-authored a paper in 1986 with David Rumelhart and Ronald J. Williams, which popularized the backpropagation algorithm.
- Hinton is considered a leading figure in the deep learning community and was awarded the Turing Award in 2018 with Yoshua Bengio and Yann LeCun.
- Hinton's research includes investigations into neural networks for machine learning, memory, perception, and symbol processing.
- Hinton has been honored with numerous awards, including the Herzberg Canada Gold Medal for Science and Engineering, and the BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award.
- Hinton is related to several notable figures, including the mathematician Mary Everest Boole and the logician George Boole.
- Hinton has expressed disapproval of military funding of artificial intelligence and has petitioned against autonomous weapons.
- He is optimistic about AI's impact on the job market but believes that AGI won't make humans redundant.
- Hinton lost his second wife to ovarian cancer in 1994.
George Novacky:
- George A. Novacky was an Assistant Department Chair and Senior Lecturer in Computer Science, and an Assistant Dean of CAS for Undergraduate Studies at the University of Pittsburgh.
- He received a mathematics degree from Wheeling Jesuit College in 1968, followed by an MA in mathematics in 1971 and a PhD in mathematics in 1981 from the University of Pittsburgh.
- Novacky's dissertation was on the chromaticity of extremal graphs.
- He was an Associate Professor of Mathematics at the Community College of Allegheny County from 1977 to 1985.
- He has been a faculty member of the University of Pittsburgh's Department of Computer Science since 1985.
- Novacky received The Chancellor's Distinguished Teaching Award in 1993.
- He has published three books including "Computers and Networks: A Laboratory Approach to Computer Literacy", "Computer Applications & the Internet" (co-authored with Y. Khalifa), and "PDA Programming in C" (co-authored with Yasir Khalifa).
George Sadowsky:
- George Sadowsky is an American computer scientist who has worked extensively in developing countries to bring affordable internet and minimize government control and regulation.
- He was inducted into the Internet Hall of Fame as a Global Connector in 2013 and received the Johnathan B. Postel award in 2022.
- Sadowsky has a background in mathematics and economics, with degrees from Harvard and Yale.
- He held various roles in academia and research, including Director of Academic Computing and Network Services at New York University and Executive Director of the GIPI project.
- Sadowsky served on various boards, including the Nominating Committee of ICANN, the Board of Directors for the Digital Policy Institute, and the IT Advisory Council for Bulgarian President Georgi Parvanov.
- He has also been a member of the Election Committee of the Internet Society and serves on the Board of Directors of Peoplink and the Board of Advisers of Bridge to Asia.
Gerald Jay Sussman:
- Gerald Jay Sussman is the Panasonic Professor of Electrical Engineering at MIT
- He received his S.B. and Ph.D. degrees in mathematics from MIT
- Sussman has been involved in AI research since 1964
- His research focuses on problem-solving strategies and formalizing them for more effective education
- Sussman has worked in computer languages, computer architecture, and Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) design
- Sussman co-authored the computer science textbook Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs
- He has made contributions to AI in problem-solving, CAD, and electrical circuit analysis and synthesis
- Sussman co-invented the programming language Scheme with Guy L. Steele Jr.
- He is a fellow of several organizations including the IEEE and the ACM and has received multiple teaching awards
- Sussman is also involved in the free software movement and is a bonded locksmith and member of various organizations including the AWI and the ARRL
- Sussman is married to computer programmer Julie Sussman
- A selection of his bibliography is listed, including Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs and Structure and Interpretation of Classical Mechanics
Gerard Holzmann:
- Gerard J. Holzmann is a Dutch-American computer scientist and researcher at Bell Labs and NASA.
- He received an Engineer's degree and PhD from Delft University of Technology.
- He worked as an assistant professor at Delft University and at Bell Labs in the Computing Science Research Center.
- He joined NASA in 2003 and leads the NASA JPL Laboratory for Reliable Software.
- Holzmann created the SPIN model checker in the 1980s, which can verify the correctness of concurrent software.
- He has received various awards, including the Prof. Bahler Prize, the Software System Award, and the IEEE Harlan D. Mills Award.
- Holzmann has published several books, including The Spin Model Checker - Primer and Reference Manual and Design and Validation of Computer Protocols.
Gerard Salton:
- Gerard A. "Gerry" Salton was a Professor of Computer Science at Cornell University and the "father of Information Retrieval"
- He developed the SMART Information Retrieval System, which was the first system to use the vector space model for Information Retrieval
- Salton was born in Germany and received a Bachelor's and Master's degree in mathematics from Brooklyn College, and a Ph.D. from Harvard in applied mathematics
- He is best known for developing the vector space model and TF-IDF (term-frequency-inverse-document frequency) for Information Retrieval
- He published over 150 research articles and 5 books during his life and was editor-in-chief of the Communications of the ACM and the Journal of the ACM
- Salton was an ACM Fellow, received an Award of Merit from the American Society for Information Science, and was the first recipient of the SIGIR Award for outstanding contributions to the study of Information Retrieval (now called the Gerard Salton Award)
- Bibliography includes "Automatic Information Organization and Retrieval," "A Theory of Indexing," and "Automatic Text Processing"
- See also: List of pioneers in computer science
Gernot Heiser:
- Gernot Heiser is a Scientia Professor and the John Lions Chair for operating systems at UNSW Sydney.
- He joined UNSW Sydney in 1991 as a lecturer and became a full professor in 2002, a position he still holds.
- He co-led NICTA's Embedded, Real-Time and Operating Systems program from its inception in 2002 to its transformation into the Software Systems Research Group in 2011, which he led.
- He is the founding chairman of the seL4 Foundation since April 2020.
- He focuses his research on microkernels, microkernel-based systems, and virtual machines, emphasizing performance and reliability.
- His group developed Mungi, a single address space operating system for clusters and implementations of the L4 microkernel with fast IPC communication.
- His research shifted towards embedded systems at NICTA, leading to the development of the seL4 microkernel and its formal verification for functional correctness.
- He has worked on paravirtualization, device drivers, virtual NUMA, energy management, and microarchitectural timing channels.
- He has received various awards and recognitions, such as the ACM SIGOPS Hall of Fame Award in 2019 and the NSW Scientist of the Year award in 2009.
Gerrit Blaauw:
- Gerrit Anne "Gerry" Blaauw was a Dutch computer scientist who played a major role in the design of the IBM System/360 line of computers.
- He received his BA from Delft University of Technology and his MA and PhD from Harvard University.
- Blaauw worked for IBM and designed the unsuccessful IBM 8000 series, but was a key engineer on the successful IBM System/360 project.
- He designed the revolutionary address translation system, the "Blaauw Box", which was later used in IBM's unsuccessful proposal to MIT's Project MAC and in the IBM System/360-67 computer.
- After leaving IBM, Blaauw became a computer science professor and retired from the University of Twente in 1989 as professor emeritus.
- Blaauw was a devout Christian and explored science and faith in a booklet available in English, Dutch, and Spanish.
- Selected publications by Blaauw include Digital System Implementation (1976) and Computer Architecture: Concepts and Evolution (1997).
- Blaauw died in Utrecht in 2018.
Gillian Lovegrove:
- Gillian Lovegrove is a retired computer scientist and academic.
- Lovegrove was Dean of the School of Informatics at Northumbria University.
- She was president of the Conference of Professors and Heads of Computing and a Higher Education consultant to the British Computer Society.
- Lovegrove is known for her interest in gender imbalance in computer education and employment and for discussing solutions to a shortage of information technology graduates in the UK.
- Lovegrove studied at Newnham College, Cambridge and started her career as a lecturer in mathematics at Portsmouth Polytechnic.
- Lovegrove conducted research on object-oriented computing and co-wrote two papers about girls and computer education.
- Lovegrove organised "Women into Computing" conferences in the late 1980s.
- Lovegrove was associate dean and head of information systems at the University of Staffordshire's School of Computing.
- Lovegrove gave evidence on the shortage of IT graduates to the Parliamentary Information Technology Committee in 2001 and proposed joint teaching schemes between employers and universities.
- Lovegrove was head-hunted by Northumbria University in 1999 to be Head of the School of Informatics.
Gio Wiederhold:
- Gio Wiederhold was a computer scientist who spent most of his career at Stanford University.
- He focused his research on the design and protection of large-scale database management systems, often using knowledge-based techniques.
- Wiederhold was born in Italy in 1936 and emigrated to the United States in 1958.
- He worked on short-range missile trajectories at NATO's Air Defense Technical Center and at IBM's service bureau before joining UC Berkeley in 1962 to develop incremental compiling technology.
- Wiederhold joined the faculty of Stanford University in 1976 and integrated knowledge base technology with artificial intelligence concepts to provide intelligent and efficient access to databases.
- He authored several books on database management systems and was named a fellow of various organizations such as the American College of Medical Informatics, the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, and the Association for Computing Machinery.
- In later career, Wiederhold worked on various projects such as model-based transformation of relational database information, architectural concepts for mediators, and a high-level programming language for software composition.
- He retired in 2001 and continued to work as a consultant for the U.S. Treasury on assessing the values of intellectual property exported from the U.S. as part of offshoring.
- Wiederhold authored and coauthored over 400 published papers and reports and received an honorary doctorate from NUI Galway in 2011.
- He died on December 26, 2022, at the age of 86.
Glen Culler:
- Glen Jacob Culler was an American professor of electrical engineering
- He was an early innovator in the development of the Internet
- He joined the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) faculty in 1959
- He helped put the campus in the forefront of computer science
- He later founded his own company, Culler-Harrison, which became CHI Systems and later Culler Scientific
- His son David Culler is also a notable computer scientist
- He developed the Culler-Fried Online System, one of the first interactive computer systems
- The system used a storage oscilloscope for graphical information and provided an innovative means of teaching mathematical concepts
- He was chosen by ARPA to be one of the first four nodes on the original ARPANET in 1969
- Culler-Harrison is considered a precursor to the founding of Floating Point Systems, Inc. and the Very Long Instruction Word (VLIW) architecture
- He received the National Medal of Technology from President Bill Clinton in 2000
- He was also a recipient of the Seymour Cray Computer Science and Engineering Award from the IEEE.
Gloria Townsend:
- Gloria Townsend is an American computer scientist and professor.
- She works at DePauw University in Indiana.
- She is known for her work in evolutionary computation and her involvement with women in computing.
- Townsend has served on the Executive Committee of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Council on Women in Computing.
- She is the author of One Hundred One Ideas for Small Regional Celebrations of Women in Computing.
- She received the Mr. and Mrs. Fred C. Tucker Jr. Distinguished Career Award in 2013.
- In 2006, she organized regional celebrations of Women in Computing to coincide with the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing conference.
- In 2010, the celebrations were extended to 12 regions as a joint effort by ACM-W, ABI, and NCWIT.
- Townshend has published papers on topics such as general education courses, mentors and role models, and leveling the CS1 playing field.
- She is affiliated with the Association for Computing Machinery's Council on Women in Computing (ACM-W).
Godfried Toussaint:
- Godfried Theodore Patrick Toussaint was a Canadian computer scientist and a professor of computer science at New York University Abu Dhabi.
- He is considered to be the father of computational geometry in Canada and conducted research on various aspects of computational and discrete geometry.
- Toussaint was a co-founder of the Annual ACM Symposium on Computational Geometry and the Annual Canadian Conference on Computational Geometry.
- He developed the Akl-Toussaint algorithm for the construction of the convex hull of a planar point set.
- Toussaint applied mathematical methods to the analysis of symbolically represented music and discovered the Euclidean algorithm for computing the greatest common divisor of two numbers implicitly generates almost all the most important traditional rhythms of the world.
- He was the recipient of several prestigious awards for his contributions to the field of computer science.
- Toussaint authored several books and book chapters on topics in computational geometry and computer science.
Gordon Bell:
- Chester Gordon Bell is an American electrical engineer and manager
- He worked at Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) from 1960 to 1966, designing several PDP machines and becoming Vice President of Engineering from 1972 to 1983, overseeing the development of the VAX computer systems
- He later became an entrepreneur and investor, founding Encore Computer and Ardent Computer, and established the Gordon Bell Prize in 1987 to encourage development in parallel processing
- Bell also became involved in public policy, becoming the founding Assistant Director of the CISE Directorate of the NSF in the 1980s
- He later became a researcher emeritus at Microsoft Research from 1995 to 2015, working on the MyLifeBits project
- Bell was elected a member of the National Academy of Engineering in 1977 and has received several other honors and awards throughout his career
- He is also a co-founder of the Computer History Museum and has authored several books.
Gordon Cormack:
- Gordon Villy Cormack is a professor at the University of Waterloo.
- He co-invented Dynamic Markov Compression.
- His research with Maura R. Grossman has been cited in legal cases in the US, Ireland, and the UK.
- Since 2001, he has been a program committee member of The Text Retrieval Conference.
- Cormack coached Waterloo's ACM International Collegiate Programming Contest team from 1997-2010.
- He was a member of the International Olympiad in Informatics Scientific Committee from 2004-2011.
- Cormack received his education from University of Manitoba and was a faculty member at McGill University before joining the University of Waterloo.
Gordon Moore:
- Gordon Earle Moore is an American businessman, engineer, and co-founder of Intel Corporation.
- He is the original proponent of Moore's law, which predicts that the number of components in a dense integrated circuit doubles approximately every two years.
- Moore studied chemistry and physics at the University of California, Berkeley, and received a Ph.D. in chemistry from the California Institute of Technology.
- He worked at Fairchild Semiconductor before co-founding Intel Corporation with Robert Noyce in 1968.
- He has a net worth of $7 billion as of February 2023.
- Moore and his wife established the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation in 2000, through which they support environmental conservation, science, and nursing care.
- Moore has received many awards and honors for his contributions to the semiconductor industry, including the National Medal of Technology and Innovation, Presidential Medal of Freedom, IEEE Medal of Honor, and Dan David Prize.
- He is also an avid sport fisherman and conservationist.
Greg Nelson (computer scientist):
- Charles Gregory Nelson was an American computer scientist born on 27 March 1953 and died on 2 February 2015.
- He grew up in Honolulu and had a talent for gymnastics and tennis.
- He received his B.A. degree in mathematics from Harvard University in 1976 and his Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University in 1980 under the supervision of Robert Tarjan.
- His thesis was titled "Techniques for Program Verification".
- He contributed to program verification, automated theorem proving, and satisfiability modulo theories.
- He received the Herbrand Award in 2013 for his pioneering contributions to theorem proving and program verification.
- He played a key role in developing the Simplify theorem prover.
- He made significant contributions in programming language design, distributed systems, constraint-based graphics editors, windowing systems, optimal code generation, and multi-threaded programming.
- He settled permanently in the San Francisco Bay Area after living in Juneau, Alaska for a year.
- He is listed in the Wikipedia articles: List of computer scientists and List of programmers.
Gregor Kiczales:
- Gregor Kiczales is a computer scientist and full time professor at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, Canada.
- He is best known for developing the concept of aspect-oriented programming and the AspectJ extension to the Java programming language.
- He is a co-author of the specification for the Common Lisp Object System and authored the book The Art of the Metaobject Protocol.
- Kiczales' work focuses on allowing software engineers to create programs that look like their design to reduce complexity and improve software quality.
- He started his research career at the MIT Lab for Computer Science and later joined the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center where he developed his most important research works.
- Kiczales left PARC in 1999 to focus on computer science education and joined the Department of Computer Science at the University of British Columbia in 2000.
- He designed CPSC 110, the introductory programming course in the UBC curriculum, which focuses on systematic program design by means of design recipes.
- Kiczales co-founded Intentional Software with Charles Simonyi in 2002 but left in 2003 to return to UBC.
- In 2012, he won the Senior AITO Dahl-Nygaard Prize for his work on the Common Lisp Object System and was named an ACM Fellow.
- He was appointed executive director of UBC Extended Learning in July 2017.
Gregory Chaitin:
- Gregory John Chaitin is a mathematician and computer scientist.
- He made contributions to algorithmic information theory and metamathematics.
- He is considered one of the founders of algorithmic complexity.
- Chaitin's constant Ω is a real number with properties that make it definable but not computable.
- He is also interested in questions of metabiology and information-theoretic formalizations of the theory of evolution.
- Chaitin has written books on philosophy, including metaphysics and philosophy of mathematics.
- He defends a position known as digital philosophy and proposes a quasi-empirical methodology in mathematics.
- He has received several honors, including degrees of doctor of science and professorship.
- Chaitin's interpretations and conclusions have been subject to criticism and disagreement from some philosophers and logicians.
- He has published several books and articles on his work and ideas.
- Chaitin's work draws attention from computer scientists, philosophers, and mathematicians alike.
Grzegorz Rozenberg:
- Grzegorz Rozenberg is a computer scientist from Poland and the Netherlands.
- His primary research areas include natural computing, formal language and automata theory, graph transformations, and concurrent systems.
- He is known as the "guru of natural computing" for promoting the discipline and giving it its current name and scope in the 1970s.
- Rozenberg has been a professor at Leiden University in the Netherlands since 1979 and is also an adjoint professor at the University of Colorado at Boulder in the US.
- He has authored over 500 papers and 6 books, and co-edited over 100 books and special issues of scientific journals.
- Rozenberg founded or co-founded and served as the chair for several computer science conferences and organizations.
- He has received numerous honors and awards for his contributions to computer science, including being named a Foreign Member of the Finnish Academy of Sciences and Letters and being appointed Knight in the Order of the Netherlands Lion.
- Rozenberg is also a performing magician under the name Bolgani and is the father of Dutch artist Dadara.
Guido van Rossum:
- Guido van Rossum is a Dutch programmer who created the Python programming language.
- He was the "benevolent dictator for life" of Python until he stepped down from the position in 2018.
- Van Rossum received a master's degree in mathematics and computer science from the University of Amsterdam in 1982.
- He worked for various research institutes, including the Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica in the Netherlands, the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology, and the Corporation for National Research Initiatives.
- From 2005 to 2012, he worked at Google, where he spent half of his time developing Python and created the web-based code review system Mondrian.
- In 2013, he joined Dropbox and officially retired in 2019.
- In 2020, he announced that he was coming out of retirement to join the Developer Division at Microsoft as a Distinguished Engineer.
- Van Rossum submitted a funding proposal to DARPA in 1999 called "Computer Programming for Everybody," in which he further defined his goals for Python, including making it an easy and intuitive language, open source, and suitable for everyday tasks.
- He has received various awards, including the 2001 Award for the Advancement of Free Software from the Free Software Foundation and the 2018 Fellow of the Computer History museum.
- Guy Lewis Steele Jr. is an American computer scientist who played a key role in designing and documenting several computer programming languages and technical standards.
- He received his education from Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
- Steele worked at various organizations, including Carnegie Mellon University, Tartan Laboratories, Thinking Machines, Sun Microsystems, and Oracle.
- He has contributed to the design of Lisp and its implementation, the Scheme language, the command set of Emacs, and the development of TeX.
- Steele served on accredited technical standards committees, including the X3J11 for C, X3J3 for Fortran, Ecma International (formerly European Computer Manufacturers Association (ECMA)) TC39 for ECMAScript, and X3J13 for Common Lisp.
- He coauthored several books, including "The Hacker's Dictionary," "C: A Reference Manual," "Common Lisp the Language," "The High Performance Fortran Handbook," and "The Java Language Specification."
- Steele received multiple awards and honors throughout his career, including the ACM Grace Murray Hopper Award and being named an ACM Fellow, a member of the National Academy of Engineering of the United States of America, and a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
- He is also a modern western square dancer and has published light verse and "Crunchly" cartoons under the pseudonym Great Quux.
G\u00e1bor Tardos:
- Gábor Tardos is a Hungarian mathematician.
- He is currently a professor at Central European University and was previously a Canada Research Chair at Simon Fraser University.
- Tardos works mainly in combinatorics and computer science.
- He received his PhD in Mathematics from Eötvös University, Budapest in 1988 and held postdoctoral posts at the University of Chicago, Rutgers University, University of Toronto, and the Princeton Institute for Advanced Study.
- Tardos received several awards, including the European Mathematical Society prize for young researchers, the Prize of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences for Young Researchers, the Erdős Prize from the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, and the Alfréd Rényi Prize.
- He received a Lendület Grant from the Hungarian Academy of Sciences in 2009, and in 2020, he received the Gödel Prize for the algorithmic version of the Lovász local lemma that he developed with Robin Moser.
- Tardos is the younger brother of Éva Tardos, who is also a renowned mathematician.
- Tardos worked on several mathematical results, including exhibiting a maximal clone of order-preserving operations that is not finitely generated, obtaining partial results concerning the Hanna Neumann conjecture, and proving a combinatorial conjecture of Zoltán Füredi and Péter Hajnal that was known to imply the Stanley–Wilf conjecture.
- He also developed a method for optimal probabilistic fingerprint codes and worked out an algorithm that is easy to implement.
- Tardos was an invited speaker at the International Congress of Mathematicians in Rio de Janeiro in 2018.
- His selected publications include papers on optimal probabilistic fingerprint codes, transversals of 2-intervals, on the power of randomization in on-line algorithms, and a maximal clone of monotone operations which is not finitely generated.
Hans Moravec:
- Hans Peter Moravec is a futurist and adjunct faculty member at the Robotics Institute of Carnegie Mellon University.
- He is known for his work on robotics, artificial intelligence, and the impact of technology.
- Moravec developed techniques in computer vision for determining the region of interest in a scene.
- He received his BSc in mathematics from Acadia University and his MSc in computer science from the University of Western Ontario.
- His PhD thesis at Stanford University involved a TV-equipped robot that could negotiate cluttered obstacle courses.
- Moravec co-founded Seegrid Corporation, a robotics company.
- In his book Mind Children, he predicts the evolution of robots into a new species, starting around 2030-2040.
- Moravec also outlined the "neural substitution argument" in Mind Children, which suggests that consciousness does not depend on biology and can be transferred to an electronic computer.
- In his book Robot: Mere Machine to Transcendent Mind, he predicts a coming "mind fire" of rapidly expanding superintelligence.
- Moravec's work is related to artificial general intelligence, mind uploading, simulated reality, space elevators, and the technological singularity.
Hans Zantema:
- Hans Zantema is a Dutch mathematician and computer scientist.
- He is a professor at Radboud University in Nijmegen.
- Zantema received his PhD in algebraic number theory at the University of Amsterdam in 1983.
- He worked in the computer science industry from 1987 to 2000 at Utrecht University and since 2000 at Eindhoven University of Technology.
- Zantema's main achievements are in term rewriting systems, specifically in proving termination.
- He is known for Zantema's problem, which asks if the string rewrite system 0011 -> 111000 terminates.
- Selected publications include his PhD thesis and articles on termination of term rewriting. 
- Zantema's homepage can be found on the website of his university.
Hardik Gohel:
- Hardik Gohel is a computer scientist and educational leader.
- He is a faculty member and director of Applied Artificial Intelligence(AAI) laboratory at University of Houston at Victoria (UHV).
- Gohel is the AI/ML research faculty at University of Houston Hewlett Packard Enterprise Data Science Institute.
- He is also a Senior Member of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) and executive faculty advisor of an international science group at UHV.
- Gohel has research experience in artificial intelligence, digital healthcare, cybersecurity, and advanced computing.
- He has received his Ph.D. in computer science from University of Hertfordshire, England, and his bachelor's and master's degree in computer science from Saurashtra University and Sardar Patel University, India.
- Gohel has 70 publications in the journals and proceedings of national and international conferences.
- He has received various grants, including postdoctoral travel grant, summer research grant, and multiyear collaborative federal STEM grant.
- In 2022, UHV has received the first federal contract for research, and Gohel is the principal investigator on this project.
- Gohel has formed a UHV student branch of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), and he is associated with virtual converges of international tech communities by webinars and virtual datascience summer bootcamps for high school students.
- Gohel has authored several books on topics such as data visualization, computational approaches for novel therapeutic and diagnostic designing, and Introduction to Network & Cyber Security.
- He has received academic and research excellence awards from Computer Society of India, and senior membership from the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).
Harry Bouwman:
- Willem Adriaan Gerrit Anton Bouwman is a Dutch Information systems researcher and professor at Åbo Akademi University.
- Bouwman has worked on mobile services, business models, and business architecture.
- He holds an MA in political science from VU University Amsterdam, a PhD from Radboud University Nijmegen, and a degree in computer science from Open University in the Netherlands.
- Bouwman has been an assistant professor at the University of Amsterdam and an associate professor at the University Utrecht and Delft University of Technology.
- He has also been a visiting professor at Syracuse University and Northwestern University.
- Bouwman is the author of books such as "Mobile Service Innovation and Business Models" and "Information and Communication Technology in Organizations: Adoption, Implementation, Use and Effects".
- He has also contributed to articles on topics such as click-and-mortar electronic commerce, advanced mobile services acceptance, and business architecture.
Haskell Curry:
- Haskell Brooks Curry was an American mathematician and logician born on September 12, 1900, in Millis, Massachusetts.
- Curry is best known for his work in combinatory logic and his development of the concept.
- Curry's work focused on attempts to show that combinatory logic could provide a foundation for mathematics.
- He also played a significant role in high-level programming language and the development of a procedure to convert general arithmetic expression into computer code.
- Curry taught at Harvard, Princeton, and Pennsylvania State University for most of his career and retired from the University of Amsterdam in 1970.
- He published major works such as "Foundations of Mathematical Logic" and "Combinatory Logic."
- Curry died on September 1, 1982, in State College, Pennsylvania.
- Haskell, Brook, and Curry, three programming languages, are named after him along with the concept of currying used for functions in math and computer science.
Hector Garcia-Molina:
- Héctor García-Molina was a Mexican-American computer scientist and professor at Stanford University.
- He advised Google co-founder Sergey Brin from 1993 to 1997 when Brin was a student at Stanford.
- García-Molina received his bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering from the Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Studies (ITESM) and both a master's degree in Electrical Engineering and a doctorate in Computer Science from Stanford University.
- He worked at Princeton University from 1979 to 1991 before joining the faculty of Stanford University in 1992.
- García-Molina served on the U.S. President's Information Technology Advisory Committee (PITAC) and was a member of Oracle Corporation's Board of Directors.
- He received various awards, including the VLDB 10-year Best Paper Award, SIGMOD Best Demo Award, and an honorary doctorate from ETH Zurich.
- García-Molina died of cancer at the age of 65.
Herbert W. Franke:
- Herbert W. Franke was an Austrian scientist and writer who was born on 14 May 1927 and died on 16 July 2022

- He was known as "the most prominent German writing Science Fiction author"

- Franke was an early computer artist who created computer graphics and early digital art starting from the late 1950s

- He was also active in the fields of future research and speleology

- Franke used his pen name Sergius Both as his Avatar name in Active Worlds and Opensimulator grids

- The Sergius Both Award is given for creative scripting in Immersionskunst by Stiftung Kunstinformatik

- Franke received his doctorate in theoretical physics in 1950

- He was a co-founder of Ars Electronica in Linz, Austria

- Franke held a lectureship in "Cybernetical Aesthetic" at Munich University from 1973 to 1997

- Some of Franke's well-known publications include "The Magic of Molecules," "The Orchid Cage," and "The Mind Net"

- Franke won several awards, including the Deutscher Science Fiction Preis, the Kurd Lasswitz prize, and the Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and Art, 1st class

- His works are part of museum collections such as the Abteiberg Museum and the Victoria and Albert Museum

- Herbert W. Franke's archive is at ZKM | Center for Art and Media Karlsruhe.
